Recovery map stability for the Data Processing Inequality

Eric A. Carlen Department of Mathematics, Hill Center, Rutgers University, 110 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854-8019, USA Anna Vershynina Department of Mathematics, Philip Guthrie Hoffman Hall, University of Houston, 3551 Cullen Blvd., Houston, TX 77204-3008, USA
Abstract

The Data Processing Inequality (DPI) says that the Umegaki relative entropy S(ρ||σ):=Tr[ρ(logρ−logσ)]S(\rho||\sigma):=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho(\log\rho-\log\sigma)] is non-increasing under the action of completely positive trace preserving (CPTP) maps. Let ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} be a finite dimensional von Neumann algebra and 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} a von Neumann subalgebra of it. Let ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} be the tracial conditional expectation from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. For density matrices ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, let ρ𝒩:=ℰτ​ρassignsubscript𝜌𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{N}}:={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\rho and σ𝒩:=ℰτ​σassignsubscript𝜎𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜎\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}:={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\sigma. Since ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} is CPTP, the DPI says that S(ρ||σ)≥S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)S(\rho||\sigma)\geq S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}), and the general case is readily deduced from this. A theorem of Petz says that there is equality if and only if σ=ℛρ​(σ𝒩)𝜎subscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}), where ℛρsubscriptℛ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} is the Petz recovery map, which is dual to the Accardi-Cecchini coarse graining operator 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. We prove a quantitative version of Peta’s theorem. In it simplest form, our bound is

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π8)4∥Δσ,ρ∥−2∥ℛρ(σ𝒩)−σ∥14.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{8}\right)^{4}\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|^{-2}\|{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})-\sigma\|_{1}^{4}\ .\

where Δσ,ρsubscriptΔ𝜎𝜌\Delta_{\sigma,\rho} is the relative modular operator. Since ‖Δσ,ρ‖≤‖ρ−1‖normsubscriptΔ𝜎𝜌normsuperscript𝜌1\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|\leq\|\rho^{-1}\|, this bound implies a bound with a constant that is independent of σ𝜎\sigma. We also prove an analogous result with a more complicated constant in which the roles of ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma are interchanged on the right.

Explicitly describing the solutions set of the Petz equation σ=ℛρ​(σ𝒩)𝜎subscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}) amounts to determining the set of fixed points of the Accardi-Cecchini coarse graining map. Building on previous work, we provide a throughly detailed description of the set of solutions of the Petz equation ℛρ​(ℰτ​γ)=γsubscriptℛ𝜌subscriptℰ𝜏𝛾𝛾{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\gamma)=\gamma, and obtain all of our results in a simple, self contained manner. Finally, we prove a theorem characterizing state ρ𝜌\rho for which the orthogonal projection from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product is a conditional expectation.

1 Introduction

1.1 The Data Processing Inequality

Let ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} be a finite dimensional von Neumann algebra, which we may regard as a subalgebra of Mn​(ℂ)subscript𝑀𝑛ℂM_{n}({\mathbb{C}}), the n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n complex matrices. The Hilbert-Schmidt inner product ⟨⋅,⋅⟩H​Ssubscript⋅⋅𝐻𝑆\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{HS} on Mn​(ℂ)subscript𝑀𝑛ℂM_{n}({\mathbb{C}}) is given in terms of the trace by ⟨X,Y⟩H​S=Tr​[X∗​Y]subscript𝑋𝑌𝐻𝑆Trdelimited-[]superscript𝑋𝑌\langle X,Y\rangle_{HS}=\mathrm{Tr}[X^{*}Y]. Let 𝟏1{\bf 1} denote the identity.

A state on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} is a linear functional φ𝜑\varphi on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} such that φ​(A∗​A)≥0𝜑superscript𝐴𝐴0\varphi(A^{*}A)\geq 0 for A∈ℳ𝐴ℳA\in{\mathcal{M}} and such that φ​(𝟏)=1𝜑11\varphi({\bf 1})=1. A state φ𝜑\varphi is faithful in case φ​(A∗​A)>0𝜑superscript𝐴𝐴0\varphi(A^{*}A)>0 whenever A≠0𝐴0A\neq 0, and is tracial in case φ​(A​B)=φ​(B​A)𝜑𝐴𝐵𝜑𝐵𝐴\varphi(AB)=\varphi(BA) for all A,B∈ℳ𝐴𝐵ℳA,B\in{\mathcal{M}}. Every state on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} is of the form X↦Tr​[ρ​X]maps-to𝑋Trdelimited-[]𝜌𝑋X\mapsto\mathrm{Tr}[\rho X], where ρ𝜌\rho is a density matrix in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}; i.e., a non-negative element ρ𝜌\rho of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} such that Tr​[ρ]=1Trdelimited-[]𝜌1\mathrm{Tr}[\rho]=1. This state is faithful if and only if ρ𝜌\rho is invertible. It will be convenient to write ρ​(X)=Tr​[ρ​X]𝜌𝑋Trdelimited-[]𝜌𝑋\rho(X)=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho X] to denote the state corresponding to a density matrix ρ𝜌\rho. Given a faithful state ρ𝜌\rho, the corresponding Gelfand-Naimark-Segal (GNS) inner product is given by ⟨X,Y⟩G​N​S,ρ:=ρ​(X∗​Y)assignsubscript𝑋𝑌𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌𝜌superscript𝑋𝑌\langle X,Y\rangle_{GNS,\rho}:=\rho(X^{*}Y).

In this finite dimensional setting, there is always a faithful tracial state τ𝜏\tau on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, namely the one whose density matrix is n−1​𝟏superscript𝑛11n^{-1}{\bf 1}. The symbol τ𝜏\tau is reserved throughout for this tracial state.

Let 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} be a von Neumann subalgebra of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} be any norm-contractive projection from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. (Norm contractive means that ‖ℰ​(X)‖≤‖X‖normℰ𝑋norm𝑋\|{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X)\|\leq\|X\| for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}}. Throughout the paper, ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| without any subscript denotes the operator norm.) By a theorem of Tomiyama [37], ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} preserves positivity, ℰ​(𝟏)=𝟏ℰ11{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}({\bf 1})={\bf 1}, and

ℰ​(A​X​B)=A​ℰ​(X)​Bfor​all​A,B∈𝒩,X∈ℳ.formulae-sequenceℰ𝐴𝑋𝐵𝐴ℰ𝑋𝐵forall𝐴formulae-sequence𝐵𝒩𝑋ℳ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(AXB)=A{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X)B\qquad{\rm for\ all}\quad A,B\in{\mathcal{N}},\ X\in{\mathcal{M}}\ . (1.1)

Moreover, as Tomiyama noted, it follows from (1.1) and the positivity preserving property of ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} that

ℰ​(X)∗​ℰ​(X)≤ℰ​(X∗​X)for​all​X∈ℳ,formulae-sequenceℰsuperscript𝑋ℰ𝑋ℰsuperscript𝑋𝑋forall𝑋ℳ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X)^{*}{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X)\leq{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X^{*}X)\qquad{\rm for\ all}\ X\in{\mathcal{M}}\ , (1.2)

In fact, more is true. As is well known, every norm contractive projection is completely positive.

A conditional expectation from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, in the sense of Umegaki [41, 42, 43], is a unital projection from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} that is order preserving and such that (1.1) and (1.2) are satisfied. Since every conditional expectation ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} is a unital completely positive map, its adjoint with respect to the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product, ℰ†superscriptℰ†{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}^{\dagger}, is a completely positive trace preserving (CPTP) map, also known as a quantum operation. (Throughout this paper, a dagger ††\dagger always denotes the adjoint with respect to the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product.)

Let ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} denote the orthogonal projection from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} with respect to the GNS inner product determined by τ𝜏\tau. It is easy to see, using the tracial nature of τ𝜏\tau, that ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} is in fact a conditional expectation, and since ℰτ=ℰτ†subscriptℰ𝜏superscriptsubscriptℰ𝜏†{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}^{\dagger}, ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} is a quantum operation.

1.1 Definition.

For any state ρ𝜌\rho on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}} denotes the state on 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} given by ρ𝒩:=ℰτ​(ρ)assignsubscript𝜌𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{N}}:={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho) where, as always ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} denotes the tracial conditional expectation onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}.

The restriction of a state ρ𝜌\rho on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is of course a state on 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and as such, it is represented by a unique density matrix belonging to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, which is precisely ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}}.

1.2 Example.

Let ℋ=ℋ1⊗ℋ2ℋtensor-productsubscriptℋ1subscriptℋ2{\mathcal{H}}={\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2} be the tensor product of two finite dimensional Hilbert spaces. Let ℳ=ℬ​(ℋ)ℳℬℋ{\mathcal{M}}={\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}) be the algebra of all linear transformations on ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}, and let 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} be the subalgebra 𝟏ℋ1⊗ℬ​(ℋ2)tensor-productsubscript1subscriptℋ1ℬsubscriptℋ2{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{1}}\otimes{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{2}) consisting of all operators in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} of the form 𝟏ℋ1⊗Atensor-productsubscript1subscriptℋ1𝐴{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{1}}\otimes A, A∈ℬ​(ℋ2)𝐴ℬsubscriptℋ2A\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{2}). Then for the normalized trace τ𝜏\tau, ℰτ​(X)=d1−1​𝟏ℋ1⊗Tr1​Xsubscriptℰ𝜏𝑋tensor-productsuperscriptsubscript𝑑11subscript1subscriptℋ1subscriptTr1𝑋{\mathcal{E}}_{\tau}(X)=d_{1}^{-1}{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{1}}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{1}X for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}} where d1subscript𝑑1d_{1} is the dimension of ℋ1subscriptℋ1{\mathcal{H}}_{1} and where Tr1subscriptTr1\mathrm{Tr}_{1} denotes the partial trace over ℋ1subscriptℋ1{\mathcal{H}}_{1}.

Given two states ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, the Umegaki relative entropy of ρ𝜌\rho with respect to σ𝜎\sigma is defined [44] by

S(ρ||σ):=Tr[ρ(logρ−logσ)].S(\rho||\sigma):=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho(\log\rho-\log\sigma)]\ . (1.3)

Lindblad’s inequality [19] states that with ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} being the tracial conditional expectation onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}},

S(ρ||σ)≥S(ℰτ(ρ)||ℰτ(σ)).S(\rho||\sigma)\geq S({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho)||{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\sigma))\ . (1.4)

Lindblad showed that the monotonicity (1.4) is equivalent to the joint convexity of the relative entropy (ρ,σ)↦S(ρ||σ)(\rho,\sigma)\mapsto S(\rho||\sigma), and this in turn is an immediate consequence of Lieb’s Concavity Theorem [16]. In the case that ℳ=ℬ​(ℋ1⊗ℋ2)ℳℬtensor-productsubscriptℋ1subscriptℋ2{\mathcal{M}}={\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2}) and 𝒩={𝟏ℋ1⊗A{\mathcal{N}}=\{{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{1}}\otimes A, A∈ℬ(ℋ2)}A\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{2})\}, (1.4) was proved by Lieb and Ruskai [18], who showed it to be equivalent to the Strong Subadditivity (SSA) of the von Neumann entropy; more information on SSA is contained in Section 5.

Using the fact that Stinesping’s Dilation Theorem [33] relates general CPTP maps to tracial expectation, Lindblad [20] was able to prove, using (1.4) that for any CPTP map 𝒫𝒫{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}},

S(ρ||σ)≥S(𝒫(ρ)||𝒫(σ)).S(\rho||\sigma)\geq S({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}(\rho)||{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}(\sigma))\ . (1.5)

This is known as the Data Processing Inequality (DPI). Because of the simple relation between (1.4) and (1.5) the problem of determining the cases of equality in the Data Processing Inequality largely comes down the problem of determining the cases of equality in (1.4), which was solved by Petz [27, 28]. His necessary and sufficient condition for equality in (1.4) is closely connected with the problem of quantum coarse graining, and in particular a quantum coarse graining operation introduced by Acardi and Cecchini [2], whose dual is now now known as the Petz recovery channel, the CPTP map ℛρsubscriptℛ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} given by

ℛρ​(γ)=ρ1/2​(ρ𝒩−1/2​γ​ρ𝒩−1/2)​ρ1/2.subscriptℛ𝜌𝛾superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\gamma)=\rho^{1/2}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\gamma\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2})\rho^{1/2}\ . (1.6)

It is obvious that ℛρ​(ρ𝒩)=ρsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜌𝒩𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})=\rho, so that ℛρsubscriptℛ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} “recovers” ρ𝜌\rho from ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}}. Petz proved [27, 28] that there is equality in (1.4) if and only if

ℛρ​(σ𝒩)=σsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})=\sigma (1.7)

and that this is true if and only if

ℛσ​(ρ𝒩)=ρ.subscriptℛ𝜎subscript𝜌𝒩𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})=\rho\ . (1.8)

There has been much recent work on stability for for the DPI: [13, 17, 32, 34, 35, 46]. Suppose that ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma are such that there is approximate equality in (1.4). To what extent do ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma provide approximate solutions to Pets’s equation (1.7) and (1.8)?

1.2 Main results

In this paper we further develop an approach that we introduced in [9] for proving stability for analogs of the DPI for Rényi relative entropies. The Rényi relative entropies include the Umegaki relative entropy (1.3) as a limiting case, but taking advantage of the special structure on the Umegaki relative entropy, we are able to sharpen the stability bounds obtained in [9] for this case. Our results in this direction are given in Theorem 1.5 and Corollary 1.7. These results are proved in Section 2.

Moreover, we show how the approach introduced in [9] yields a simple specification of the structure of the pairs of densities ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma that satisfy Petz’s equations (1.7) and (1.8). This is a question that was first dealt with by Hayden, Jozsa, Petz and Winter in [14]. The question arose there because, although it is known (and explained in the appendix) that the DPI is equivalent to the quantum Strong Subadditivity of the Entropy (SSA) [18], it is not so simple to translate Petz’s condition for equality in the DPI into the condition for equality in SSA. This was done in [14], but Petz himself, together with Mosnyi, returned to the problem of determining the structure of solutions of (1.7) and (1.8) in [23]. Here we give simple specification of the structure of solutions providing some new information. Our main results in this direction are given in Theorem 1.9 and Corollary 1.10. These results are proved in Section 3.

As explained in the next two subsections, the questions considered here are closely related to several questions concerning quantum conditional expectations and quantum “coarse graining”. in Section 4, we prove a theorem specifying conditions under which the orthogonal projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is a conditional expectations, and hence, when expectation preserving conditional expectations exist. The full statement is given in Theorem 4.1.

Before giving precise statements, it will be useful to recall the relatively simple situation regarding the classical DPI.

1.3 The classical DPI

It will be useful to recall some aspects of the classical analog of the DPI. Let ΩΩ\Omega be a finite set. Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be a non-trivial partition of ΩΩ\Omega. Let ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} denote the functions on ΩΩ\Omega, and let 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} the functions on ΩΩ\Omega that are constant on each set of the partition ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. Then ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} and 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} are commutative von Neumann algebras, and 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is a subalgebra of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let X𝑋X be a function on ΩΩ\Omega such that X​(ω)=X​(ω′)𝑋𝜔𝑋superscript𝜔′X(\omega)=X(\omega^{\prime}) if and only ω𝜔\omega and ω′superscript𝜔′\omega^{\prime} belong to the same set in ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. Then X𝑋X generates ℱℱ\mathcal{F} in the sense that the sets constituting ℱℱ\mathcal{F} are precisely the non-empty sets of the form {ω​X​(ω)=x}𝜔𝑋𝜔𝑥\{\omega\>\ X(\omega)=x\}.

Let ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma be two strictly positive probability densities on the set ΩΩ\Omega. Let τ𝜏\tau denote the uniform probability density on ΩΩ\Omega; i.e., τ​(ω)=|Ω|−1𝜏𝜔superscriptΩ1\tau(\omega)=|\Omega|^{-1} for all ω𝜔\omega, where |Ω|Ω|\Omega| is the cardinality of ΩΩ\Omega. As above, let ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} denote the orthogonal projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, which is nothing other than the conditional expectation with respect the random variable Y𝑌Y and the probability measure τ𝜏\tau. As above, let ρ𝒩=ℰτ​ρsubscript𝜌𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\rho and σ𝒩=ℰτ​σsubscript𝜎𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜎\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\sigma. It is clear the ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}} is a “coarse grained” version of ρ𝜌\rho, obtained by averaging ρ𝜌\rho on the sets of the partition ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, making it constant on these.

Let f​(ω|y)𝑓conditional𝜔𝑦f(\omega|y) be the conditional density under ρ𝜌\rho for ω𝜔\omega given Y​(ω)𝑌𝜔Y(\omega), and likewise let g​(ω|y)𝑔conditional𝜔𝑦g(\omega|y) be the conditional density under σ𝜎\sigma for ω𝜔\omega given Y​(ω)𝑌𝜔Y(\omega). That is

f​(ω|x)=ρ​(ω)ρ𝒩​(x)​and​g​(ω|x)=σ​(ω)ρ𝒩​(x),𝑓conditional𝜔𝑥𝜌𝜔subscript𝜌𝒩𝑥and𝑔conditional𝜔𝑥𝜎𝜔subscript𝜌𝒩𝑥f(\omega|x)=\frac{\rho(\omega)}{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(x)}\quad{\rm and}\quad g(\omega|x)=\frac{\sigma(\omega)}{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(x)}\ , (1.9)

which, for each x𝑥x in the range of X𝑋X are both probability densities on the set {ω​X​(ω)=x}𝜔𝑋𝜔𝑥\{\omega\>\ X(\omega)=x\}.

Then we have ρ​(ω)=ρ𝒩​(X​(ω))​f​(ω|X​(ω))𝜌𝜔subscript𝜌𝒩𝑋𝜔𝑓conditional𝜔𝑋𝜔\rho(\omega)=\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(X(\omega))f(\omega|X(\omega)) and σ​(ω)=σ𝒩​(X​(ω))​g​(ω|X​(ω))𝜎𝜔subscript𝜎𝒩𝑋𝜔𝑔conditional𝜔𝑋𝜔\sigma(\omega)=\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}(X(\omega))g(\omega|X(\omega)), and hence

S(ρ||σ)\displaystyle S(\rho||\sigma) =\displaystyle= ∑ω∈Ωρ​(ω)​(log⁡ρ​(ω)−log⁡σ​(ω))subscript𝜔Ω𝜌𝜔𝜌𝜔𝜎𝜔\displaystyle\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}\rho(\omega)(\log\rho(\omega)-\log\sigma(\omega)) (1.10)
=\displaystyle= ∑ω∈Ωρ​(ω)​([log⁡ρ𝒩​(ω)−log⁡σ𝒩​(ω)]+[log⁡f​(ω|X​(ω))−log⁡g​(ω|X​(ω))])subscript𝜔Ω𝜌𝜔delimited-[]subscript𝜌𝒩𝜔subscript𝜎𝒩𝜔delimited-[]𝑓conditional𝜔𝑋𝜔𝑔conditional𝜔𝑋𝜔\displaystyle\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}\rho(\omega)([\log\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(\omega)-\log\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}(\omega)]+[\log f(\omega|X(\omega))-\log g(\omega|X(\omega))])
=\displaystyle= S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)+∑ω∈Ωρn(X(ω))[f(ω|X(ω))logf(ω|X(ω))−logg(ω|X(ω))]\displaystyle S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})+\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}\rho_{n}(X(\omega))\left[f(\omega|X(\omega))\log f(\omega|X(\omega))-\log g(\omega|X(\omega))\right]

For each x𝑥x in the range of X𝑋X, it follows from Jensen’s inequality that

∑{ω:X​(ω)=x}f​(ω|x)​[log⁡f​(ω|x)−log⁡g​(ω|x)]≥0,subscriptconditional-set𝜔𝑋𝜔𝑥𝑓conditional𝜔𝑥delimited-[]𝑓conditional𝜔𝑥𝑔conditional𝜔𝑥0\sum_{\{\omega\ :\ X(\omega)=x\}}f(\omega|x)\left[\log f(\omega|x)-\log g(\omega|x)\right]\geq 0\ , (1.11)

and there is equality if and only if f​(ω|x)=g​(ω|x)𝑓conditional𝜔𝑥𝑔conditional𝜔𝑥f(\omega|x)=g(\omega|x) everywhere on {ω:X​(ω)=x}conditional-set𝜔𝑋𝜔𝑥\{\omega\ :\ X(\omega)=x\}. It follows that S(ρ||σ)≥S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)S(\rho||\sigma)\geq S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}) with equality if and only if for each x𝑥x in the range of X𝑋X, f​(ω|x)=g​(ω|x)𝑓conditional𝜔𝑥𝑔conditional𝜔𝑥f(\omega|x)=g(\omega|x) everywhere on {ω:X​(ω)=x}conditional-set𝜔𝑋𝜔𝑥\{\omega\ :\ X(\omega)=x\}.

In this case, X𝑋X is called a sufficient statistic for the pair {ρ,σ}𝜌𝜎\{\rho,\sigma\}. Suppose we are given an independent identically distributed sequence of points {ωj}subscript𝜔𝑗\{\omega_{j}\}, drawn according to one of the two probability densities ρ𝜌\rho or σ𝜎\sigma, and we want to determine which it is. If we know the function f​(ω|x)𝑓conditional𝜔𝑥f(\omega|x), it suffices to observe the sequence {X​(ωj)}𝑋subscript𝜔𝑗\{X(\omega_{j})\}, and to determine which of ρ𝒩​(x)subscript𝜌𝒩𝑥\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(x) or σ𝒩​(x)subscript𝜎𝒩𝑥\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}(x) is governing its distribution.

Indeed, we can define a classical recovery map as follows: For any probability density γ∈𝒩𝛾𝒩\gamma\in{\mathcal{N}}, regarded as a probability density on the range of X𝑋X, define ℛρ​γsubscriptℛ𝜌𝛾{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\gamma to be the probability density in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} given by

ℛρ​γ​(ω)=γ​(X​(ω))​f​(ω|X​(ω)).subscriptℛ𝜌𝛾𝜔𝛾𝑋𝜔𝑓conditional𝜔𝑋𝜔{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\gamma(\omega)=\gamma(X(\omega))f(\omega|X(\omega))\ .

Therefore, we can express the condition for equality in the classical DPI as ℛρ​σ𝒩=σsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}=\sigma, and evidently this is true if and only if ℛσ​ρ𝒩=ρsubscriptℛ𝜎subscript𝜌𝒩𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}=\rho. This is the classical analog of Petz’s result. Moreover, in this notation, we have that

∑ω∈Ωρn(X(ω))[f(ω|X(ω))logf(ω|X(ω))−logg(ω|X(ω))]=S(ρ||ℛσρ),\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}\rho_{n}(X(\omega))\left[f(\omega|X(\omega))\log f(\omega|X(\omega))-\log g(\omega|X(\omega))\right]=S(\rho||{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}\rho)\ ,

so that (1.10) becomes

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥S(ρ||ℛσρ).S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq S(\rho||{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}\rho)\ . (1.12)

Then by the classical Pinsker inequality,

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥12(∑ω∈Ω|ρ(ω)−ℛσρ(ω)|)2.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\frac{1}{2}\left(\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}|\rho(\omega)-{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}\rho(\omega)|\right)^{2}\ . (1.13)

It remains an open problem to prove quantum analogs of (1.12) or (1.13), even with worse constants on the right. Here we prove a quantum analog of (1.13) with a worse constant, and with the power raised from 2 to 4 on the right. The line of argument has to be entirely different from the one we have just employed in the classical case because there is no effective quantum replacement for “conditioning on the observable X𝑋X”.

It is therefore useful to find a way of describing the classical recovery map that doe not refer explicitly to conditioning on the random variable X𝑋X. Define ℰσsubscriptℰ𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma} to be the orthogonal projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in L2​(σ)superscript𝐿2𝜎L^{2}(\sigma). Then for any random variable Y𝑌Y (i.e., any function on ΩΩ\Omega), ℰσ​Ysubscriptℰ𝜎𝑌{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma}Y is the condition expectation of Y𝑌Y given the sigma-algebra ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. The operation Y↦ℰσ​Ymaps-to𝑌subscriptℰ𝜎𝑌Y\mapsto{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma}Y yields a “coarse grained version” of Y𝑌Y that is constant on the sets in ℱℱ\mathcal{F}: With X𝑋X and g𝑔g as in (1.9),

ℰσY(ω)=∑ω′:X(ω′)=X(ω)}g(ω′|X(ω)Y(ω′).{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma}Y(\omega)=\sum_{\omega^{\prime}:\ X(\omega^{\prime})=X(\omega)\}}g(\omega^{\prime}|X(\omega)Y(\omega^{\prime})\ .

It is clear from this formula that ℰσsubscriptℰ𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma} preserves positivity, and preserves expectations with respect to σ𝜎\sigma, That is,

σ​(Y)=σ​(ℰσ​Y).𝜎𝑌𝜎subscriptℰ𝜎𝑌\sigma(Y)=\sigma({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma}Y)\ . (1.14)

Now let ℰσ†superscriptsubscriptℰ𝜎†{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma}^{\dagger} be the dual operation taking states on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} (probability densities on the range of X𝑋X) to states on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} (probability densities on ΩΩ\Omega). It is easily seen that this is nothing other than ℛσsubscriptℛ𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}. That is, the classical recovery map ℛσsubscriptℛ𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma} is nothing other than the dual of the conditional expectation ℰσsubscriptℰ𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\sigma}, which is nothing other than the orthogonal projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in L2​(σ)superscript𝐿2𝜎L^{2}(\sigma). This analytic specification of ℛσsubscriptℛ𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}, making no explicit mention of conditioning on X𝑋X, provides a starting point for the construction of a quantum recovery map.

1.4 Quantum conditional expectations and quantum coarse graining

The discussion of the classical DPI brings us to the question as to whether for any faithful state ρ𝜌\rho on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} there exists a conditional expectation ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} that preserves expectations with respect to ρ𝜌\rho, i.e. such that

ρ​(X)=ρ​(ℰ​(X))for​all​X∈ℳ.formulae-sequence𝜌𝑋𝜌ℰ𝑋forall𝑋ℳ\rho(X)=\rho({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X))\qquad{\rm for\ all}\ X\in{\mathcal{M}}\ . (1.15)

The property (1.15) says that “the expectation of a conditional expectation of an observable equals the expectation of the observable”. If such a conditional expectation exists, then it is unique: Any such conditional expectation must be the orthogonal projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} on 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} with respect to the G​N​S𝐺𝑁𝑆GNS inner product for the state ρ𝜌\rho. To see this, note that for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}} and all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}, using (1.1),

⟨A,X⟩G​N​S,ρ=ρ​(A∗​X)=ρ​(ℰ​(A∗​X))=ρ​(A∗​ℰ​(X))=⟨A,ℰ​(X)⟩G​N​S,ρ.subscript𝐴𝑋𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌𝜌superscript𝐴𝑋𝜌ℰsuperscript𝐴𝑋𝜌superscript𝐴ℰ𝑋subscript𝐴ℰ𝑋𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌\langle A,X\rangle_{GNS,\rho}=\rho(A^{*}X)=\rho({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(A^{*}X))=\rho(A^{*}{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X))=\langle A,{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X)\rangle_{GNS,\rho}\ . (1.16)

Suppose that ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} is a conditional expectation satisfying (1.15). Then since ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} is a unital completely positive map, ℰ†superscriptℰ†{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}^{\dagger} is a CPTP map; i.e., a quantum channel. For any state γ𝛾\gamma on 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and any A∈ℳ𝐴ℳA\in{\mathcal{M}}, we then have

ℰ†​(A)=γ​(ℰ​(A)).superscriptℰ†𝐴𝛾ℰ𝐴{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}^{\dagger}(A)=\gamma({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(A))\ .

Then when (1.15) is satisfied, taking γ=ρ𝒩𝛾subscript𝜌𝒩\gamma=\rho_{\mathcal{N}}, we have

ℰ†​ρ𝒩​(A)=ρ𝒩​(ℰ​(A))=ρ​(A),superscriptℰ†subscript𝜌𝒩𝐴subscript𝜌𝒩ℰ𝐴𝜌𝐴{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}^{\dagger}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(A)=\rho_{\mathcal{N}}({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(A))=\rho(A)\ ,

and this means that ℰ†superscriptℰ†{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}^{\dagger} is a quantum channel that “recovers” ρ𝜌\rho from ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}}.

As we have already noted, ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} is a conditional expectation with the property (1.15). However, for non-tracial states ρ𝜌\rho, a conditional expectation satisfying (1.15) need not exist.

A theorem of Takesaki [36] says, in our finite dimensional context, that for a faithful state ρ𝜌\rho, there exists a conditional expectation ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} if and only if ρ​A​ρ−1∈𝒩𝜌𝐴superscript𝜌1𝒩\rho A\rho^{-1}\in{\mathcal{N}} for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}, and in general this is not the case. We give a short proof of this and somewhat more in Section 4: In Theorem 4.1, we prove that ℰρsubscriptℰ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\rho}, the orthogonal projection from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product with respect to ρ𝜌\rho, is real (that is, it preserves self-adjointness) if and only if ρ​A​ρ−1∈𝒩𝜌𝐴superscript𝜌1𝒩\rho A\rho^{-1}\in{\mathcal{N}} for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}. Since every order preserving linear transformation is real, this precludes the general existence of conditional expectations satisfying (1.15) whenever 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is not invariant under X↦ρ​X​ρ−1maps-to𝑋𝜌𝑋superscript𝜌1X\mapsto\rho X\rho^{-1}, thus implying Takesaki’s Theorem (in this finite dimensional setting).

There is another inner product on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} that is naturally induced by a faithful state ρ𝜌\rho, namely the Kubo-Martin-Schwinger (KMS) inner product. It is defined by

⟨X,Y⟩K​M​S,ρ=Tr​[ρ1/2​X∗​ρ1/2​Y]=Tr​[(ρ1/4​X​ρ1/4)∗​(ρ1/4​Y​ρ1/4)].subscript𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌Trdelimited-[]superscript𝜌12superscript𝑋superscript𝜌12𝑌Trdelimited-[]superscriptsuperscript𝜌14𝑋superscript𝜌14superscript𝜌14𝑌superscript𝜌14\langle X,Y\rangle_{KMS,\rho}=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho^{1/2}X^{*}\rho^{1/2}Y]=\mathrm{Tr}[(\rho^{1/4}X\rho^{1/4})^{*}(\rho^{1/4}Y\rho^{1/4})]\ . (1.17)

Evidently, for any X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}} and Y∈𝒩𝑌𝒩Y\in{\mathcal{N}},

|⟨X,Y⟩K​M​S,ρ|=|Tr​[ρ1/2​X∗​ρ1/2​Y]|subscript𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌Trdelimited-[]superscript𝜌12superscript𝑋superscript𝜌12𝑌\displaystyle|\langle X,Y\rangle_{KMS,\rho}|=|\mathrm{Tr}[\rho^{1/2}X^{*}\rho^{1/2}Y]| =\displaystyle= |Tr​[(ρ𝒩−1/4​ρ1/2​X​ρ1/2​ρ𝒩−1/4)∗​(ρ𝒩1/4​Y​ρ𝒩1/4)]|Trdelimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩14superscript𝜌12𝑋superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩14superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩14𝑌superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩14\displaystyle|\mathrm{Tr}[(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/4}\rho^{1/2}X\rho^{1/2}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/4})^{*}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/4}Y\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/4})]|
≤\displaystyle\leq ‖(ρ𝒩−1/4​ρ1/2​X​ρ1/2​ρ𝒩−1/4)‖H​S​‖Y‖K​M​S,ρ𝒩.subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩14superscript𝜌12𝑋superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩14𝐻𝑆subscriptnorm𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆subscript𝜌𝒩\displaystyle\|(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/4}\rho^{1/2}X\rho^{1/2}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/4})\|_{HS}\|Y\|_{KMS,\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}\ .

Hence Y↦⟨X,Y⟩K​M​S,ρmaps-to𝑌subscript𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌Y\mapsto\langle X,Y\rangle_{KMS,\rho} is a bounded linear functional on (𝒩,⟨⋅,⋅⟩K​M​S,ρ𝒩)𝒩subscript⋅⋅𝐾𝑀𝑆subscript𝜌𝒩({\mathcal{N}},\langle\cdot\,,\cdot\rangle_{KMS,\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}), and then there is a uniquely determined 𝒜ρ​(X)∈𝒩subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋𝒩{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)\in{\mathcal{N}} such that for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}} and all Y∈𝒩𝑌𝒩Y\in{\mathcal{N}},

⟨X,Y⟩K​M​S,ρ=⟨𝒜ρ​(X),Y⟩K​M​S,ρ𝒩.subscript𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌subscriptsubscript𝒜𝜌𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆subscript𝜌𝒩\langle X,Y\rangle_{KMS,\rho}=\langle{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X),Y\rangle_{KMS,\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}\ . (1.18)

The map 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} was introduced by Accardi and Cecchini [2], building on previous work by Accardi [1].

1.3 Definition.

Let ρ𝜌\rho be a faithful state on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. The Accardi-Cecchini coarse graining operator 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is defined by (1.18).

The map 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} was introduced by Accardi and Cecchini [2], building on previous work by Accardi [1]. It is a “coarse graining” operation in that to each observable X𝑋X in the larger algebra ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, it associates an observable 𝒜ρ​(X)subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X), in the smaller algebra 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and measurement of 𝒜ρ​(X)subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X) will yields coarser information than a measurement of X𝑋X itself. The same, of course, is true for conditional expectations,

Since 𝟏∈𝒩1𝒩{\bf 1}\in{\mathcal{N}} by definition, for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}}, ⟨𝟏,X⟩K​M​S,ρ=⟨𝟏,𝒜ρ​(X)⟩K​M​S,ρsubscript1𝑋𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌subscript1subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌\langle{\bf 1},X\rangle_{KMS,\rho}=\langle{\bf 1},{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)\rangle_{KMS,\rho}, and for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}}, ⟨𝟏,X⟩K​M​S,ρ=Tr​[σ1/2​𝟏​σ1/2​X]=ρ​(X)subscript1𝑋𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌Trdelimited-[]superscript𝜎121superscript𝜎12𝑋𝜌𝑋\langle{\bf 1},X\rangle_{KMS,\rho}=\mathrm{Tr}[\sigma^{1/2}{\bf 1}\sigma^{1/2}X]=\rho(X). Therefore

ρ​(𝒜ρ​(X))=ρ​(X).𝜌subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋𝜌𝑋\rho({\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X))=\rho(X)\ . (1.19)

Thus, unlike conditional expectations in general, the Accardi-Cecchini coarse-graining operator always preserves expectations with respect to ρ𝜌\rho.

In the matricial setting, it is a particularly simple matter to derive an explicit expression for 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}. By definition, for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}} and all Y∈𝒩𝑌𝒩Y\in{\mathcal{N}},

Tr​[ρ𝒩1/2​Y​ρ𝒩1/2​𝒜ρ​(X)]=Tr​[ρ1/2​Y​ρ1/2​X].Trdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12𝑌superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋Trdelimited-[]superscript𝜌12𝑌superscript𝜌12𝑋\mathrm{Tr}[\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}Y\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)]=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho^{1/2}Y\rho^{1/2}X]\ . (1.20)

Make the change of variables Z=ρ𝒩1/2​Y​ρ𝒩1/2𝑍superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12𝑌superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12Z=\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}Y\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}. Since ρ𝒩1/2superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2} is invertible and Y𝑌Y ranges over 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, Z𝑍Z ranges over 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. Hence

Tr​[Z​𝒜ρ​(X)]=Tr​[(ρ1/2​ρ𝒩−1/2​Z​ρ𝒩−1/2​ρ1/2)​X]=Tr​[Z​(ρ𝒩−1/2​ρ1/2​X​ρ1/2​ρ𝒩−1/2)].Trdelimited-[]𝑍subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋Trdelimited-[]superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12𝑍superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12𝑋Trdelimited-[]𝑍superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12𝑋superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12\mathrm{Tr}[Z{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)]=\mathrm{Tr}[(\rho^{1/2}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}Z\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2})X]=\mathrm{Tr}[Z(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2}X\rho^{1/2}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2})]\ . (1.21)

Since the above holds for all Z∈𝒩𝑍𝒩Z\in{\mathcal{N}}, it follows that

𝒜ρ​(X)=ρ𝒩−1/2​ℰτ​(ρ1/2​X​ρ1/2)​ρ𝒩−1/2.subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12subscriptℰ𝜏superscript𝜌12𝑋superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)=\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho^{1/2}X\rho^{1/2})\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\ . (1.22)

It is evident from this formula that 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} is a completely positive unital map from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and therefore it is actually a contraction from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. By Tomiyama’s Theorem, it cannot in general be a projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. That is, if X∈𝒩𝑋𝒩X\in{\mathcal{N}}, it is not necessarily the case that 𝒜ρ​(X)=Xsubscript𝒜𝜌𝑋𝑋{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)=X. The set of X∈𝒩𝑋𝒩X\in{\mathcal{N}} for which this is true turns out to be a subalgebra of 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, as was shown by Accardi and Cecchini [2]. This subalgebra will be of interest in what follows.

1.4 Definition.

The Petz recovery map ℛρsubscriptℛ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} is the Hilbert-Schmidt adjoint of 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} [28]. That is, ℛρ=𝒜ρ†subscriptℛ𝜌superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜌†{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}^{\dagger}, or equivalently, for all density matrices γ∈𝒩𝛾𝒩\gamma\in{\mathcal{N}}

Tr​[γ​𝒜ρ​(X)]=Tr​[ℛρ​(γ)​X].Trdelimited-[]𝛾subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋Trdelimited-[]subscriptℛ𝜌𝛾𝑋\mathrm{Tr}[\gamma{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)]=\mathrm{Tr}[{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\gamma)X]\ .

A dagger ††\dagger always denotes the adjoint with respect to the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product.

As the dual of a unital completely positive map, ℛρsubscriptℛ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} is a CPTP map. Moreover, it follows immediately from the definition and (1.22) that for all density matrices γ∈𝒩𝛾𝒩\gamma\in{\mathcal{N}},

ℛρ​(γ)=ρ1/2​(ρ𝒩−1/2​γ​ρ𝒩−1/2)​ρ1/2.subscriptℛ𝜌𝛾superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\gamma)=\rho^{1/2}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\gamma\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2})\rho^{1/2}\ . (1.23)

It is evident from this formula not only that ℛρsubscriptℛ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} is a CPTP map, but that ℛρ​(ρ𝒩)=ρsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜌𝒩𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})=\rho; i.e., ℛρsubscriptℛ𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} recovers ρ𝜌\rho from ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}}. Now suppose that σ𝜎\sigma is another density matrix in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} and that

ℛρ​(σ𝒩)=σ.subscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})=\sigma\ . (1.24)

Then by the Data Processing Inequality and (1.24), S(ρ||σ)≤S(ℛρ(ρ𝒩)||ℛρ(σ𝒩))=S(ρ||σ)S(\rho||\sigma)\leq S({\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})||{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}))=S(\rho||\sigma). Hence when ℛρ​(σ𝒩)=σsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})=\sigma, there is equality in (1.4). The deeper result of Petz [27, 28] is that there is equality in (1.4) only in this case.

Our goal is to prove a stability bound for Petz’s theorem on the cases of equality in (1.4). Our result involves the relative modular operator Δρ,σsubscriptΔ𝜌𝜎\Delta_{\rho,\sigma} on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} defined by

Δσ,ρ​(X)=σ​X​ρ−1subscriptΔ𝜎𝜌𝑋𝜎𝑋superscript𝜌1\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}(X)=\sigma X\rho^{-1} (1.25)

for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}}. This is the matricial version of an operator introduced in a more general von Neumann algebra context by Araki [3]. Our main result is:

1.5 Theorem.

Let ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma be two states on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} Let ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} be the tracial conditional expectation onto a von Neumann subalgebra 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and let ρ𝒩=ℰτ​ρsubscript𝜌𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\rho and σ𝒩=ℰτ​σsubscript𝜎𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜎\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\sigma. Then, with ∥⋅∥2\|\cdot\|_{2} denoting the Hilbert-Schmidt norm,

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π4)4∥Δσ,ρ∥−2∥σ𝒩1/2ρ𝒩−1/2ρ1/2−σ1/2∥24.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{4}\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|^{-2}\|\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2}-\sigma^{1/2}\|_{2}^{4}\ . (1.26)

The quantity on the right hand side may be estimated in terms of the Petz recovery map. In Section 2 we prove:

1.6 Lemma.

Let ρ𝜌\rho, σ𝜎\sigma and σ𝒩subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma_{\mathcal{N}} be specified as in Theorem 1.5. Then, with ∥⋅∥1\|\cdot\|_{1} denoting the trace norm,

‖(σ𝒩)1/2​(ρ𝒩)−1/2​ρ1/2−σ1/2‖2≥12​‖ℛρ​(σ𝒩)−σ‖1.subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12superscript𝜎12212subscriptnormsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎1\|(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})^{1/2}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2}-\sigma^{1/2}\|_{2}\geq\frac{1}{2}\|{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})-\sigma\|_{1}\ .

As an immediate Corollary of Theorem 1.5 and Corollary 1.6, we obtain

1.7 Corollary.

Let ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma be two states on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} be the tracial conditional expectation onto a von Neumann subalgebra 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and let ρ𝒩=ℰτ​ρsubscript𝜌𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\rho and σ𝒩=ℰτ​σsubscript𝜎𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜎\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\sigma. Then, with ∥⋅∥1\|\cdot\|_{1} denoting the trace norm,

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π8)4∥Δσ,ρ∥−2∥ℛρ(σ𝒩)−σ∥14.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{8}\right)^{4}\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|^{-2}\|{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})-\sigma\|_{1}^{4}\ . (1.27)

Note how the right hand side of (1.27) differs from the right hand side of (1.13): Apart from the constant and the power 444 in place of 222, the most striking difference is that the roles of ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma are reversed. The expected result, with a worse constant, is obtained in Corollary 1.8.

Recall that the modular operator is the right multiplication by ρ−1superscript𝜌1\rho^{-1} and left multiplication by σ𝜎\sigma, so ‖Δσ,ρ‖≤‖ρ−1‖normsubscriptΔ𝜎𝜌normsuperscript𝜌1\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|\leq\|\rho^{-1}\|, since ‖σ‖≤1.norm𝜎1\|\sigma\|\leq 1. While ‖ρ−1‖normsuperscript𝜌1\|\rho^{-1}\| might be considerably larger than ‖Δσ,ρ‖normsubscriptΔ𝜎𝜌\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|, a bound in terms of ‖ρ−1‖normsuperscript𝜌1\|\rho^{-1}\| has the merit that it is independent of σ𝜎\sigma:

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π8)4∥ρ−1∥−2∥ℛρ(σ𝒩)−σ∥14.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{8}\right)^{4}\|\rho^{-1}\|^{-2}\|{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})-\sigma\|_{1}^{4}\ . (1.28)

Corollary 1.7 yields a result of Petz: With ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma as above, S(ρ||σ)=S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)S(\rho||\sigma)=S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}) if and only if σ𝜎\sigma satisfies the Petz equation

σ=ℛρ​(σ𝒩).𝜎subscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\ . (1.29)

Theorem 1.5 gives what appears to be a stronger condition on relating ρ𝜌\rho, σ𝜎\sigma, ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}} and σ𝒩subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}, namely that

ρ𝒩−1/2​ρ1/2=σ𝒩−1/2​σ1/2.superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscript𝜎12\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2}=\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\sigma^{1/2}\ . (1.30)

While validity of (1.30) immediately implies that σ𝜎\sigma satisfies the Petz equation (1.29), the converse is also true: By what we have noted above, when (1.29) is satisfied, S(ρ||σ)=S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)S(\rho||\sigma)=S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}), and then by Theorem 1.5, (1.30) is satisfied.

This may be made quantitative as follows: Letting LAsubscript𝐿𝐴L_{A} denote the operator of left multiplication by A𝐴A,

Lρ𝒩1/2​Lσ𝒩−1/2​(σ𝒩1/2​ρ𝒩−1/2​ρ1/2−σ1/2)=(ρ1/2−ρ𝒩1/2​σ𝒩−1/2​σ1/2),subscript𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12subscript𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12superscript𝜎12superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscript𝜎12L_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}}L_{\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2}-\sigma^{1/2})=(\rho^{1/2}-\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\sigma^{1/2})\ ,

and hence

‖ρ1/2−ρ𝒩1/2​σ𝒩−1/2​σ1/2‖2≤‖Lρ𝒩1/2‖​‖Lσ𝒩−1/2‖​‖σ𝒩1/2​ρ𝒩−1/2​ρ1/2−σ1/2‖2.subscriptnormsuperscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscript𝜎122normsubscript𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12normsubscript𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12superscript𝜎122\|\rho^{1/2}-\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\sigma^{1/2}\|_{2}\leq\|L_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}}\|\|L_{\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}}\|\|\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2}-\sigma^{1/2}\|_{2}\ . (1.31)

Since ‖Lρ𝒩1/2‖=‖ρ𝒩‖1/2normsubscript𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscriptnormsubscript𝜌𝒩12\|L_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}}\|=\|\rho_{{\mathcal{N}}}\|^{1/2} and ‖Lσ𝒩−1/2‖=‖σ𝒩−1‖1/2normsubscript𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩112\|L_{\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}}\|=\|\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1}\|^{1/2}, we may combine (1.31) with (1.26) to obtain

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π4)4∥Δσ,ρ∥−2∥ρ𝒩∥−2∥σ𝒩−1∥−2∥ρ𝒩1/2σ𝒩−1/2σ1/2−ρ1/2∥24,S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{4}\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|^{-2}\|\rho_{{\mathcal{N}}}\|^{-2}\|\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1}\|^{-2}\|\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\sigma^{1/2}-\rho^{1/2}\|_{2}^{4}\ , (1.32)

which is the analog of (1.26) with a somewhat worse constant on the right, but the roles of ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma interchanged there. Applying Lemma 1.6 once more, we obtain

1.8 Corollary.

Let ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma be two states on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} be the tracial conditional expectation onto a von Neumann subalgebra 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and let ρ𝒩=ℰτ​ρsubscript𝜌𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\rho and σ𝒩=ℰτ​σsubscript𝜎𝒩subscriptℰ𝜏𝜎\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\sigma. Then

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π8)4∥Δσ,ρ∥−2∥ρ𝒩∥−2∥σ𝒩−1∥−2∥ℛσ(ρ𝒩)−ρ∥14.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{8}\right)^{4}\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|^{-2}\|\rho_{{\mathcal{N}}}\|^{-2}\|\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1}\|^{-2}\|{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})-\rho\|_{1}^{4}\ . (1.33)

As above, bounding the norms of states by 1, we get a constant that depends only on the smallest eigenvalues of ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝒩subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π8)4∥ρ−1∥−2∥σ𝒩−1∥−2∥ℛσ(ρ𝒩)−ρ∥14.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{8}\right)^{4}\|\rho^{-1}\|^{-2}\|\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1}\|^{-2}\|{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})-\rho\|_{1}^{4}\ . (1.34)

We noted above that σ𝜎\sigma solves the Petz equation if and only if (1.30) is satisfied, and then since (1.30) is symmetric in ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma, σ=ℛρ​σ𝒩𝜎subscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}} if and only if ρ=ℛσ​ρ𝒩𝜌subscriptℛ𝜎subscript𝜌𝒩\rho={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}, and hence

S(ρ||σ)=S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)⇔S(σ||ρ)=S(σ𝒩||ρ𝒩).S(\rho||\sigma)=S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\iff S(\sigma||\rho)=S(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}||\rho_{\mathcal{N}})\ . (1.35)

The reasoning leading to Corollary 1.8 show that moreover, ∥ρ=ℛσρ𝒩∥1\|\rho={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}\|_{1} and ∥σ=ℛρσ𝒩∥1\|\sigma={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}\|_{1} are comparable in size.

To state our results on the structure of the solution set of the Petz equation, we introduce the fixed point set

𝒞:={X∈ℳ:𝒜ρ​(X)=X}.assign𝒞conditional-set𝑋ℳsubscript𝒜𝜌𝑋𝑋{\mathcal{C}}:=\{X\in{\mathcal{M}}:\ {\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)=X\ \}. (1.36)

Standard results (see Section 3) show that 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} is a von Neumann subalgebra of 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. Let ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} denote the modular operator on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}},

Δρ​(X)=ρ​X​ρ−1.subscriptΔ𝜌𝑋𝜌𝑋superscript𝜌1\Delta_{\rho}(X)=\rho X\rho^{-1}\ . (1.37)

Then 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} may also be characterized (Theorem 3.3) as the largest von Neumann subalgebra of 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} that is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}.

Let 𝒵𝒵{\mathcal{Z}} denote the center of 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}. Then by standard results (see Section 3), 𝒵𝒵{\mathcal{Z}} is generated by a finite family {P1,…,PJ}subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝐽\{P_{1},\dots,P_{J}\} of mutually orthogonal projections. Define ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)}, j=1,…,J𝑗1…𝐽j=1,\dots,J, to be the range of Pjsubscript𝑃𝑗P_{j}. The restriction of 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} to each ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)} is a factor, and hence each ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)} factors as ℋj,ℓ⊗ℋj,rtensor-productsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}, and the general element A𝐴A of 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} has the form

A=∑j=1J𝟏ℋj,ℓ⊗Aj,r,𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript1subscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝐴𝑗𝑟A=\sum_{j=1}^{J}{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}\otimes A_{j,r}\ ,

where Aj,r∈ℬ​(ℋj,r)subscript𝐴𝑗𝑟ℬsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟A_{j,r}\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}). All of this follows from the standard theory of the structure of finite dimensional von Neumann algebras, and we emphasize that 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} and the decomposition ℋ=⨁j=1Jℋj,ℓ⊗ℋj,rℋsuperscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟{\mathcal{H}}=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{J}{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r} is canonically associated to ρ𝜌\rho.

Since 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}, the orthogonal projection from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho is a conditional expectation (see Theorem 4.1) that we denote by ℰ𝒞,ρsubscriptℰ𝒞𝜌{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{C}},\rho}, and which we call the conditional expectation given 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} under ρ𝜌\rho. We shall prove:

1.9 Theorem.

Let ρ𝜌\rho be a faithful state on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, and let 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} be a von Neumann subalgebra of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} be the fixed-point algebra of the Accardi-Cecchini coarse graining operator 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}. Let ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} be the finite dimensional Hilbert space on which ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} acts, and let ℋ=⨁j=1Jℋj,ℓ⊗ℋj,rℋsuperscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟{\displaystyle{\mathcal{H}}=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{J}{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}} induced by the decomposition of 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} as a direct sum of factors. Then there are uniquely determined density matrices {γ1,r,…,γJ,r}subscript𝛾1𝑟…subscript𝛾𝐽𝑟\{\gamma_{1,r},\dots,\gamma_{J,r}\}, where γj,rsubscript𝛾𝑗𝑟\gamma_{j,r} acts on ℋj,rsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r} and γj,ℓ⊗𝟏ℋj,r∈ℳtensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscript1subscriptℋ𝑗𝑟ℳ\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}}\in{\mathcal{M}} so that

ρ=⨁j=1Jγj,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​(Pj​ρ​Pj).𝜌superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃𝑗𝜌subscript𝑃𝑗\rho=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{J}\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}(P_{j}\rho P_{j})\ . (1.38)

Moreover, ℰτ​(γj,ℓ⊗𝟏ℋj,r)subscriptℰ𝜏tensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscript1subscriptℋ𝑗𝑟{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}}) has the form γ~j,ℓ⊗𝟏ℋj,rtensor-productsubscript~𝛾𝑗ℓsubscript1subscriptℋ𝑗𝑟\widetilde{\gamma}_{j,\ell}\otimes{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}} and

ρ𝒩=⨁j=1Jγ~j,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​(Pj​ρ​Pj).subscript𝜌𝒩superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript~𝛾𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃𝑗𝜌subscript𝑃𝑗\rho_{\mathcal{N}}=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{J}\widetilde{\gamma}_{j,\ell}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}(P_{j}\rho P_{j})\ . (1.39)

A state σ𝜎\sigma on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} solves the Petz equation ℛρ​σ𝒩=σsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}=\sigma if and only if for all X𝑋X in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, σ​(X)=σ​(ℰ𝒞,ρ)𝜎𝑋𝜎subscriptℰ𝒞𝜌\sigma(X)=\sigma({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{{\mathcal{C}},\rho}); i.e., if and only if expectations with respect to σ𝜎\sigma are preserved under the the conditional expectation given 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} under ρ𝜌\rho. Every such state σ𝜎\sigma has the form σ=⨁j=1Jγj,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​(Pj​σ​Pj)𝜎superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃𝑗𝜎subscript𝑃𝑗{\displaystyle\sigma=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{J}\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}(P_{j}\sigma P_{j})} for the same {γ1,r,…,γJ,r}subscript𝛾1𝑟…subscript𝛾𝐽𝑟\{\gamma_{1,r},\dots,\gamma_{J,r}\}

1.10 Corollary.

Let ρ,σ𝜌𝜎\rho,\sigma be faithful states on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, and let 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} be a von Neumann subalgebra of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} be the fixed-point algebra of the Accardi-Cecchini coarse graining operator 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} for 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. Let ℰ𝒞​ρsubscriptℰ𝒞𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{{\mathcal{C}}\rho} be the conditional expectation given 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} under ρ𝜌\rho. Define ρ𝒞=ℰ𝒞​ρ​ρsubscript𝜌𝒞subscriptℰ𝒞𝜌𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{C}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{{\mathcal{C}}\rho}\rho, σ𝒞=ℰ𝒞​ρ​σsubscript𝜎𝒞subscriptℰ𝒞𝜌𝜎\sigma_{\mathcal{C}}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{{\mathcal{C}}\rho}\sigma. Then

S(ρ||σ)=S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)⇔S(ρ||σ)=S(ρ𝒞||σ𝒞).S(\rho||\sigma)=S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\quad\iff\quad S(\rho||\sigma)=S(\rho_{\mathcal{C}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{C}})\ . (1.40)

In particular, if 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} is spanned by 𝟏1{\bf 1}, S(ρ||σ)=S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)S(\rho||\sigma)=S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}) if and only if ρ=σ𝜌𝜎\rho=\sigma.

We close the introduction with some further comments on recovery map stability bounds for the Data Processing Inequality. In physical applications, instead of the trace distance, one often consider an alternative measure of the closeness between two quantum states, the fidelity [39]. For two states ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma on ℬ​(ℋ)ℬℋ{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}), the fidelity between them is defined as

F​(ρ,σ)=‖ρ​σ‖12.𝐹𝜌𝜎superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜌𝜎12F(\rho,\sigma)=\|\sqrt{\rho}\sqrt{\sigma}\|_{1}^{2}. (1.41)

For all states ρ𝜌\rho and σ𝜎\sigma, we have 0≤F​(ρ,σ)≤10𝐹𝜌𝜎10\leq F(\rho,\sigma)\leq 1. The fidelity equal to one if and only if the states are equal, and it is equal to zero if and only is the support of ρ𝜌\rho is orthogonal to the support of σ𝜎\sigma. So in other words, the fidelity is zero when states are perfectly distinguishable, and zero when they cannot be distinguished. Note that the fidelity itself satisfies the monotonicity relation under a completely positive trace preserving maps, but we will not discuss it here. Moreover, there is a relation between the trace distance ‖ρ−σ‖1subscriptnorm𝜌𝜎1\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1} and fidelity

1−F​(ρ,σ)≤12​‖ρ−σ‖1≤1−F​(ρ,σ).1𝐹𝜌𝜎12subscriptnorm𝜌𝜎11𝐹𝜌𝜎1-\sqrt{F(\rho,\sigma)}\leq\frac{1}{2}\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{1-F(\rho,\sigma)}\ . (1.42)

From here and the Corollary 1.7 we obtain the quantitative version of the Petz’s Theorem involving the fidelity between states

S(ρ||σ)−S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≥(π4)4∥Δσ,ρ∥−2(1−F​(σ,ℛρ​(σ𝒩)))4.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{4}\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|^{-2}\left(1-\sqrt{F(\sigma,{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}))}\right)^{4}\ . (1.43)

Recent results [13, 17, 45, 46] provide sharpening of the monotonicity inequality, but the lower bounds provided there involve quantities that are hard to compute, e.g. rotated and twirled Petz recovery maps. for another fidelity type bound not explicitly involving the recover map, see [8, Theorem 2.2]. The appeal of the above bound is that it involves simple distance measure between the original state σ𝜎\sigma and Petz recovered state ℛρ​(σ𝒩)subscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}).

The proof of the theorem 1.5 also implies that satisfaction of the Petz equation ℛρ​σ𝒩=σsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}=\sigma is the necessary and sufficient condition for cases of equality in the monotonicity inequality for a large class of quasi-relative entropies, as we now briefly explain.

Let f:(0,+∞)→ℝ:𝑓→0ℝf:(0,+\infty)\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be an operator convex function, so that for all n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in{\mathbb{N}}, and all positive n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n matrices A𝐴A and B𝐵B, f(12A+12B)≤12f(A))+12f(B)f(\tfrac{1}{2}A+\tfrac{1}{2}B)\leq\tfrac{1}{2}f(A))+\tfrac{1}{2}f(B). We say that f𝑓f is strictly operator convex in case there is equality if and only if A=B𝐴𝐵A=B.

Petz [25], [26] has defined the f𝑓f-relative quasi-entropy as

Sf(ρ||σ)=Tr[f(Δσ,ρ)ρ]=⟨ρ1/2,f(Δσ,ρ)ρ1/2⟩H​S.S_{f}(\rho||\sigma)=\mathrm{Tr}[f(\Delta_{\sigma,\rho})\rho]=\langle\rho^{1/2},f(\Delta_{\sigma,\rho})\rho^{1/2}\rangle_{HS}\ . (1.44)

Since −log⁡(Δσ,ρ)​ρ1/2=ρ1/2​log⁡ρ−log⁡σ​ρ1/2subscriptΔ𝜎𝜌superscript𝜌12superscript𝜌12𝜌𝜎superscript𝜌12-\log(\Delta_{\sigma,\rho})\rho^{1/2}=\rho^{1/2}\log\rho-\log\sigma\rho^{1/2}, the choice f​(x)=−log⁡x𝑓𝑥𝑥f(x)=-\log x yields the Umegaki relative entropy.

Since for each t>0𝑡0t>0, the function x↦(t+x)−1maps-to𝑥superscript𝑡𝑥1x\mapsto(t+x)^{-1} is operator convex, this construction yields a one parameter family a quasi relative entropies, S(t)subscript𝑆𝑡S_{(t)}, defined by

S(t)(ρ||σ)=Tr[(t+Δσ,ρ)−1ρ].S_{(t)}(\rho||\sigma)=\mathrm{Tr}\left[(t+\Delta_{\sigma,\rho})^{-1}\rho\right]\ . (1.45)

From the integral representation of the logarithm

−log⁡(A)=∫0∞(1t+A−11+t)​dt,𝐴superscriptsubscript01𝑡𝐴11𝑡differential-d𝑡-\log(A)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{t+A}-\frac{1}{1+t}\right){\rm d}t\ ,

it follows that

S(ρ||σ)=∫0∞(S(t)(ρ||σ)−11+t)dt,S(\rho||\sigma)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(S_{(t)}(\rho||\sigma)-\frac{1}{1+t}\right){\rm d}t\ , (1.46)

and we may use this representation to study monotonicity for the Umegaki relative entropy in terms of monotonicity for the one parameter family of quasi relative entropies S(t)subscript𝑆𝑡S_{(t)}. The proof of Theorem 1.5 is ultimately derived from a stability bound for the variant of the Data Processing Inequality that is valid for the quasi relative entropies S(t)subscript𝑆𝑡S_{(t)}. Since the Rényi relative entropies can be expressed in terms of a similar integral representation, the Petz equation σ=ℛρ​σ𝒩𝜎subscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}} again characterizes the condition for cases of equality in these variants of the Data Processing Inequality; this will be developed in detail in a companion paper.

2 Stability for the Data Processing Inequality

We begin this section by recalling Petz’s proof of the monotonicity of the quasi relative entropies Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f} for operator convex f𝑓f.

The spectra of σ𝒩subscript𝜎𝒩\sigma_{\mathcal{N}} and ρ𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\rho_{\mathcal{N}} lie in the convex hulls of the spectra of σ𝜎\sigma and ρ𝜌\rho respectively. It follows that ‖Δσ𝒩,ρ𝒩‖≤‖Δσ,ρ‖normsubscriptΔsubscript𝜎𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩normsubscriptΔ𝜎𝜌\|\Delta_{\sigma_{\mathcal{N}},\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}\|\leq\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|. Optimizing in T𝑇T,

∎

We now prove the lemma leading from (1.26) to (1.27).

2.2 Lemma.

For any operators X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y with Tr​[X∗​X]=Tr​[Y∗​Y]=1Trdelimited-[]superscript𝑋𝑋Trdelimited-[]superscript𝑌𝑌1\mathrm{Tr}[X^{*}X]=\mathrm{Tr}[Y^{*}Y]=1. Then

‖X∗​X−Y∗​Y‖1≤2​‖X−Y‖2.subscriptnormsuperscript𝑋𝑋superscript𝑌𝑌12subscriptnorm𝑋𝑌2\|X^{*}X-Y^{*}Y\|_{1}\leq 2\|X-Y\|_{2}\ . (2.14)
Proof.

Recall that for any operator A𝐴A, ∥A∥1=sup{|Tr[ZA]:∥Z∥≤1}\|A\|_{1}=\sup\{|\mathrm{Tr}[ZA]\ :\ \|Z\|\leq 1\} where ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| denotes the operator norm. For any contraction Z𝑍Z, using cyclicity of the trace we have

|Tr​[Z​(X∗​X−Y∗​Y)]|Trdelimited-[]𝑍superscript𝑋𝑋superscript𝑌𝑌\displaystyle|\mathrm{Tr}[Z(X^{*}X-Y^{*}Y)]| ≤\displaystyle\leq |Tr​[Z​(X∗−Y∗)​X+Z​Y∗​(X−Y)]|Trdelimited-[]𝑍superscript𝑋superscript𝑌𝑋𝑍superscript𝑌𝑋𝑌\displaystyle|\mathrm{Tr}[Z(X^{*}-Y^{*})X+ZY^{*}(X-Y)]|
≤\displaystyle\leq |Tr[(X∗−Y∗)XZ|+|Tr[ZY∗(X−Y)]\displaystyle|\mathrm{Tr}[(X^{*}-Y^{*})XZ|+|\mathrm{Tr}[ZY^{*}(X-Y)]
≤\displaystyle\leq (Tr(X∗−Y∗)(X−Y)])1/2(Tr[X∗Z∗ZX])1/2\displaystyle(\mathrm{Tr}(X^{*}-Y^{*})(X-Y)])^{1/2}(\mathrm{Tr}[X^{*}Z^{*}ZX])^{1/2}
+\displaystyle+ (Tr(X∗−Y∗)(X−Y)])1/2(Tr[Y∗Z∗ZY])1/2\displaystyle(\mathrm{Tr}(X^{*}-Y^{*})(X-Y)])^{1/2}(\mathrm{Tr}[Y^{*}Z^{*}ZY])^{1/2}
≤\displaystyle\leq 2​‖X−Y‖2.2subscriptnorm𝑋𝑌2\displaystyle 2\|X-Y\|_{2}\ .

∎

Applying this with X=(σ𝒩)1/2​(ρ𝒩)−1/2​ρ1/2𝑋superscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12X=(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})^{1/2}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2} and Y=σ1/2𝑌superscript𝜎12Y=\sigma^{1/2}, we get

‖(σ𝒩)1/2​(ρ𝒩)−1/2​ρ1/2−σ1/2‖2≥12​‖ℛρ​(σ𝒩)−σ‖1.subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝒩12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12superscript𝜌12superscript𝜎12212subscriptnormsubscriptℛ𝜌subscript𝜎𝒩𝜎1\|(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})^{1/2}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})^{-1/2}\rho^{1/2}-\sigma^{1/2}\|_{2}\geq\frac{1}{2}\|{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})-\sigma\|_{1}\ .

3 Structure of the solution set of the Petz equation

Define the CPTP map Φ:ℳ→ℳ:Φ→ℳℳ\Phi:{\mathcal{M}}\to{\mathcal{M}} by

Φ:=ℛρ∘ℰτ.assignΦsubscriptℛ𝜌subscriptℰ𝜏\Phi:={\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}\circ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\ . (3.1)

The Petz equation (1.29) can be written as Φ​(σ)=σΦ𝜎𝜎\Phi(\sigma)=\sigma. The adjoint of ΦΦ\Phi, is the completely positive unital map Φ†=Ψ:𝒩→𝒩:superscriptΦ†Ψ→𝒩𝒩\Phi^{\dagger}=\Psi:{\mathcal{N}}\to{\mathcal{N}} given by

Ψ:=ι𝒩,ℳ∘𝒜ρassignΨsubscript𝜄𝒩ℳsubscript𝒜𝜌\Psi:=\iota_{{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}}\circ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}\ (3.2)

where ι𝒩,ℳsubscript𝜄𝒩ℳ\iota_{{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}} is the inclusion of 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}.

The problem of determining all of the states fixed by ΦΦ\Phi is closely related to the problem of determining all of the fixed points of ΨΨ\Psi in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. This problem has been investigated in a general context by Lindblad [21] in the proof of his General No-cloning Theorem, drawing on earlier work by Choi and Kadison. It was also investigated in this specific context by Accardi and Cecchini. For now, we need not assume that ΨΨ\Psi is given by (3.2). For now, all we require is that ΨΨ\Psi is a unital completely positive map from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, and that its Hilbert-Schmidt dual ΦΦ\Phi has a faithful invariant state ρ𝜌\rho.

Then, by an often used argument, the map ΨΨ\Psi is a contraction on (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩G​N​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{GNS,\rho}): By the operator Schwarz inequality, for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}}, Ψ​(X)∗​Ψ​(X)≤Ψ​(X∗​X)Ψsuperscript𝑋Ψ𝑋Ψsuperscript𝑋𝑋\Psi(X)^{*}\Psi(X)\leq\Psi(X^{*}X). Then

‖Ψ​(X)‖G​N​S,ρ2=ρ​(Ψ​(X)∗​Ψ​(X))≤ρ​(Ψ​(X∗​X))=Φ​(ρ)​(X∗​X)=‖X‖G​N​S,ρ2.superscriptsubscriptnormΨ𝑋𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌2𝜌Ψsuperscript𝑋Ψ𝑋𝜌Ψsuperscript𝑋𝑋Φ𝜌superscript𝑋𝑋superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑋𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌2\|\Psi(X)\|_{GNS,\rho}^{2}=\rho(\Psi(X)^{*}\Psi(X))\leq\rho(\Psi(X^{*}X))=\Phi(\rho)(X^{*}X)=\|X\|_{GNS,\rho}^{2}\ .

Define

𝒞={X∈𝒩:Ψ​(X)=X},𝒞conditional-set𝑋𝒩Ψ𝑋𝑋\mathcal{C}=\{X\in{\mathcal{N}}\ :\ \Psi(X)=X\ \}\ , (3.3)

which is evidently a subspace. Let ℰ𝒞subscriptℰ𝒞{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\mathcal{C}} be the orthogonal projection in (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩G​N​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{GNS,\rho}) onto 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}. Then, arguing as in [21], by the von Neumann Mean Ergodic Theorem,

ℰ𝒞​(X)=limN→∞1N​∑j=1NΨj​(X),subscriptℰ𝒞𝑋subscript→𝑁1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁superscriptΨ𝑗𝑋{{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}(X)=\lim_{N\to\infty}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\Psi^{j}(X)\ ,

The following lemma may be found in [21]; we give the short proof for the reader’s convenience.

3.1 Lemma.

Let ΦΦ\Phi be a CPTP map on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, and let Ψ=Φ†ΨsuperscriptΦ†\Psi=\Phi^{\dagger}. A density matrix τ∈ℳ𝜏ℳ\tau\in{\mathcal{M}} satisfies Φ​(τ)=τΦ𝜏𝜏\Phi(\tau)=\tau if and only if it satisfies ℰ𝒞†​(τ)=τsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝒞†𝜏𝜏{{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}^{\dagger}(\tau)=\tau.

Proof.

Let τ𝜏\tau be any density matrix τ𝜏\tau in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} such that Φ​(τ)=τΦ𝜏𝜏\Phi(\tau)=\tau For all N𝑁N and all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}},

Tr(τX)=1N∑j=1N(Tr(Φj(τ)X)=1N∑j=1NTr(τΨj(X)).\mathrm{Tr}(\tau X)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}(\mathrm{Tr}(\Phi^{j}(\tau)X)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\mathrm{Tr}(\tau\Psi^{j}(X))\ .

In the limit, we obtain Tr​(τ​X)=Tr​(τ​ℰ𝒞​(X))=Tr​(ℰ𝒞†​(τ)​X)Tr𝜏𝑋Tr𝜏subscriptℰ𝒞𝑋Trsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝒞†𝜏𝑋\mathrm{Tr}(\tau X)=\mathrm{Tr}(\tau{{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}(X))=\mathrm{Tr}({{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}^{\dagger}(\tau)X). Hence τ=ℰ𝒞†​τ𝜏superscriptsubscriptℰ𝒞†𝜏\tau={{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}^{\dagger}\tau.

Now suppose that τ𝜏\tau is any density matrix in ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} satisfying τ=ℰ𝒞†​τ𝜏superscriptsubscriptℰ𝒞†𝜏\tau={{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}^{\dagger}\tau. Since evidently, Ψ∘ℰ𝒞=ℰ𝒞∘Ψ=ℰ𝒞Ψsubscriptℰ𝒞subscriptℰ𝒞Ψsubscriptℰ𝒞\Psi\circ{{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}={{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}\circ\Psi={{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}, for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}},

Tr(τX)=Tr(ℰ𝒞†(τ)X)=Tr(τ,(ℰ𝒞(X)))=Tr(τ,(ℰ𝒞(ΨX)))=Tr(τ,Ψ(X)))=Tr(Φ(τ)X).\mathrm{Tr}(\tau X)=\mathrm{Tr}({{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}^{\dagger}(\tau)X)=\mathrm{Tr}(\tau,({{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}(X)))=\mathrm{Tr}(\tau,({{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}}_{\mathcal{C}}(\Psi X)))=\mathrm{Tr}(\tau,\Psi(X)))=\mathrm{Tr}(\Phi(\tau)X)\ .

since X𝑋X is arbitrary, Φ​(τ)=τΦ𝜏𝜏\Phi(\tau)=\tau. ∎

Furthermore, by results of Choi [5] and Lindblad [21], 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is a unital ∗*-subalgebra of 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. Let 𝒵𝒵{\mathcal{Z}} denote the center of 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}, which is commutative von Neumann algebra. Because 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} is commutative, it has a particularly simple structure: If P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q are two orthogonal projections in 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}, then P​Q=Q​P𝑃𝑄𝑄𝑃PQ=QP is also an orthogonal projection in 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}. Since 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} is the closed linear span of the projections contained in it, one easily deduces the existence of a family {P1,…,PJ}subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝐽\{P_{1},\dots,P_{J}\} of mutually orthogonal projections summing to the identity such that 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} is the span of these projections.

Define ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)}, j=1,…,J𝑗1…𝐽j=1,\dots,J, to be the range of Pjsubscript𝑃𝑗P_{j}. Then the Hilbert space ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} on which ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} acts can be decomposed as ℋ=⨁j=1Jℋ(j)ℋsuperscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗1𝐽superscriptℋ𝑗{\displaystyle{\mathcal{H}}=\bigoplus_{j=1}^{J}{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)}}. (The notation is chosen to avoid confusion with tensor product decompositions such as, e.g., ℋ=ℋ1⊗ℋ2ℋtensor-productsubscriptℋ1subscriptℋ2{\mathcal{H}}={\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2} for bipartite systems.) Then each ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)} is invariant under 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, and the center of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} restricted to each ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)} is trivial – it is spanned by Pjsubscript𝑃𝑗P_{j}, the identity on ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)}. Therefore, the restriction of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} to each ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)} is a factor – a ∗*-subalgebra of ℬ​(ℋ)ℬℋ{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}) with a trivial center. By the well-known structure theorem for finite dimensional factors, ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)} can be factored as ℋ(j)=ℋj,ℓ⊗ℋj,rsuperscriptℋ𝑗tensor-productsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)}={\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r} and

𝒞j=1ℋj,ℓ⊗ℬ​(ℋj,r).subscript𝒞𝑗tensor-productsubscript1subscriptℋ𝑗ℓℬsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟\mathcal{C}_{j}=1_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}\otimes{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{j,r})\ .

Using this decomposition and structure theorem, Lindblad proves [21, Section 4] the following, stated here in terms of the notation set above:

3.2 Lemma.

Let ΨΨ\Psi be a unital completely positive map on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, where ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} acts on a finite dimensional Hilbert space ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}, and where Ψ†superscriptΨ†\Psi^{\dagger} leaves a faithful state ρ𝜌\rho invariant. Let ℰ𝒞subscriptℰ𝒞{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{{\mathcal{C}}} be the orthogonal projection onto 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}, the C∗superscript𝐶C^{*} algebra of fixed points of ΨΨ\Psi, with respect to the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho. Then there are uniquely determined density matrices {γ1,ℓ,…,γJ,ℓ}subscript𝛾1ℓ…subscript𝛾𝐽ℓ\{\gamma_{1,\ell},\dots,\gamma_{J,\ell}\}, where γj,rsubscript𝛾𝑗𝑟\gamma_{j,r} acts on ℋj,rsubscriptℋ𝑗𝑟{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}, such that for all Y∈ℳ𝑌ℳY\in{\mathcal{M}},

ℰ𝒞​(Y)=∑j=1J1ℋj,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​[(γj,ℓ⊗1ℋj,r)​Pj​Y​Pj],subscriptℰ𝒞𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript1subscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓdelimited-[]tensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscript1subscriptℋ𝑗𝑟subscript𝑃𝑗𝑌subscript𝑃𝑗{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{{\mathcal{C}}}(Y)=\sum_{j=1}^{J}1_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}[(\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes 1_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,r}})P_{j}YP_{j}]\ ,

where Trℋj,ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓ\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}} denotes the trace over ℋj,ℓsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓ{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}.

From this explicit description of ℰ𝒞subscriptℰ𝒞{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{{\mathcal{C}}}, one readily deduces that

ℰ𝒞†​(τ)=∑j=1Jγj,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​(Pj​τ​Pj)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝒞†𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃𝑗𝜏subscript𝑃𝑗{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\mathcal{C}}^{\dagger}(\tau)=\sum_{j=1}^{J}\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}(P_{j}\tau P_{j})\ (3.4)

where γj,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​(Pj​τ​Pj)tensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃𝑗𝜏subscript𝑃𝑗\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}(P_{j}\tau P_{j}) is defined as operators on all of ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} by setting it to zero on the orthogonal complement of ℋ(j)superscriptℋ𝑗{\mathcal{H}}^{(j)}. Hence τ=ℰ𝒞†​(τ)𝜏superscriptsubscriptℰ𝒞†𝜏\tau={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\mathcal{C}}^{\dagger}(\tau) if and only if τ𝜏\tau is given by the right hand side of (3.4).

Now return to the case at hand, in which ΦΦ\Phi and ΨΨ\Psi are given by (3.1) and (3.2) respectively.

Proof of Theorem 1.9.

Since Φ​ρ=ρΦ𝜌𝜌\Phi\rho=\rho, Lemma 3.1, Lemma 3.2 and (3.4) yield

ρ=∑j=1Jγj,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​(Pj​ρ​Pj)𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript𝛾𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃𝑗𝜌subscript𝑃𝑗\rho=\sum_{j=1}^{J}\gamma_{j,\ell}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}(P_{j}\rho P_{j}) (3.5)

with the set {γ1,ℓ,…,γJ,ℓ}subscript𝛾1ℓ…subscript𝛾𝐽ℓ\{\gamma_{1,\ell},\dots,\gamma_{J,\ell}\} determined by 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}, the fixed point algebra of Ψ=ι𝒩,ℳ⋅𝒜ρΨ⋅subscript𝜄𝒩ℳsubscript𝒜𝜌\Psi=\iota_{{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}}\cdot{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}.

Next observe that 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} is a von Neumann subalgebra of 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and is in fact that fixed point algebra of Ψ~:=𝒜ρ∘ι𝒩,ℳassign~Ψsubscript𝒜𝜌subscript𝜄𝒩ℳ\widetilde{\Psi}:={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}\circ\iota_{{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}} as well as of Ψ=ι𝒩,ℳ∘𝒜ρΨsubscript𝜄𝒩ℳsubscript𝒜𝜌\Psi=\iota_{{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}}\circ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}. Since Φ~:=Ψ~†=ℰτ∘ℛρassign~Φsuperscript~Ψ†subscriptℰ𝜏subscriptℛ𝜌\widetilde{\Phi}:=\widetilde{\Psi}^{\dagger}={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}\circ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}, we have Φ~​ρ𝒩=ρ𝒩~Φsubscript𝜌𝒩subscript𝜌𝒩\widetilde{\Phi}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}=\rho_{\mathcal{N}} and Φ~​σ𝒩=σ𝒩~Φsubscript𝜎𝒩subscript𝜎𝒩\widetilde{\Phi}\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}=\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}. Using Lemma 3.1, Lemma 3.2 and (3.4) once more, we see that for some {γ~i,ℓ,…,γ~J,ℓ}subscript~𝛾𝑖ℓ…subscript~𝛾𝐽ℓ\{\widetilde{\gamma}_{i,\ell},\dots,\widetilde{\gamma}_{J,\ell}\}, where for each j𝑗j, γ~j,ℓsubscript~𝛾𝑗ℓ\widetilde{\gamma}_{j,\ell} is a density matrix on ℋj,ℓsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓ{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}

ρ𝒩=∑j=1Jγ~j,ℓ⊗Trℋj,ℓ​(Pj​ρ𝒩​Pj).subscript𝜌𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽tensor-productsubscript~𝛾𝑗ℓsubscriptTrsubscriptℋ𝑗ℓsubscript𝑃𝑗subscript𝜌𝒩subscript𝑃𝑗\rho_{\mathcal{N}}=\sum_{j=1}^{J}\widetilde{\gamma}_{j,\ell}\otimes\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{j,\ell}}(P_{j}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}P_{j})\ . (3.6)

Now observe that we may factor

(3.10)

3.3 Theorem.

Let 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} be defined by (3.3) and Ψ:=ι𝒩,ℳ∘𝒜ρassignΨsubscript𝜄𝒩ℳsubscript𝒜𝜌\Psi:=\iota_{{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}}\circ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}, and let ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}} be any other von Neumann subalgebra of 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} that is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}. Then ℬ⊂𝒞ℬ𝒞{\mathcal{B}}\subset{\mathcal{C}}.

Proof.

Let ℰτ,ℬsubscriptℰ𝜏ℬ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau,{\mathcal{B}}} denote the tracial conditional expectation onto ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}, and define ρℬ:=ℰτ,ℬ​ρassignsubscript𝜌ℬsubscriptℰ𝜏ℬ𝜌\rho_{\mathcal{B}}:={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau,{\mathcal{B}}}\rho. Let 𝒜ρ,ℬ,𝒩subscript𝒜𝜌ℬ𝒩{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{N}}}, 𝒜ρ,𝒩,ℳsubscript𝒜𝜌𝒩ℳ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}} and 𝒜ρ,ℬ,ℳsubscript𝒜𝜌ℬℳ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{M}}} be the Accardi-Cecchini coarse graining operators from 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} to ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}, ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} and ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}}. A simple computation shows that

𝒜ρ,ℬ,ℳ=𝒜ρ,ℬ,𝒩∘𝒜ρ,𝒩,ℳ.subscript𝒜𝜌ℬℳsubscript𝒜𝜌ℬ𝒩subscript𝒜𝜌𝒩ℳ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{M}}}={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{N}}}\circ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}}\ . (3.12)

Let 𝒫ℬsubscript𝒫ℬ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\mathcal{B}} denote the orthogonal projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}} with respect to the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho. Since ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} leaves ℬℬ{\mathcal{B}} invariant, by (2) of Theorem 4.1 𝒜ρ,ℬ,ℳ=𝒫ℬsubscript𝒜𝜌ℬℳsubscript𝒫ℬ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{M}}}={\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\mathcal{B}}. We claim that 𝒜ρ,ℬ,𝒩subscript𝒜𝜌ℬ𝒩{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{N}}} is the restriction of 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. Indeed, by the defining relation (1.18), for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}} and all Y∈ℬ𝑌ℬY\in{\mathcal{B}},

⟨X,Y⟩K​M​S,ρ=⟨𝒜ρ,ℬ,ℳ​(X),Y⟩K​M​S,ρℬ.subscript𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆𝜌subscriptsubscript𝒜𝜌ℬℳ𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑀𝑆subscript𝜌ℬ\langle X,Y\rangle_{KMS,\rho}=\langle{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{M}}}(X),Y\rangle_{KMS,\rho_{\mathcal{B}}}\ . (3.13)

Tautologically, this holds for all X∈𝒩𝑋𝒩X\in{\mathcal{N}} and all Y∈ℬ𝑌ℬY\in{\mathcal{B}}, and so for all X∈𝒩𝑋𝒩X\in{\mathcal{N}}, 𝒜ρ,ℬ,𝒩​(X)=𝒜ρ,ℬ,ℳ​(X)subscript𝒜𝜌ℬ𝒩𝑋subscript𝒜𝜌ℬℳ𝑋{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{N}}}(X)={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{B}},{\mathcal{M}}}(X). We therefore have that for all B∈B𝐵𝐵B\in B

B=𝒫ρ​B=𝒫ρ​B∘𝒜ρ,𝒩,ℳ​(B),𝐵subscript𝒫𝜌𝐵subscript𝒫𝜌𝐵subscript𝒜𝜌𝒩ℳ𝐵B={\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}B={\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}B\circ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}}(B)\ , (3.14)

and this implies that B=𝒜ρ,𝒩,ℳ​(B)𝐵subscript𝒜𝜌𝒩ℳ𝐵B={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho,{\mathcal{N}},{\mathcal{M}}}(B), which, by definition, means that B∈𝒞𝐵𝒞B\in{\mathcal{C}}. ∎

4 Conditional expectations

Recall from the introduction that if ρ𝜌\rho is a faithful state on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} and 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is a von Neumann subalgebra of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, then there exists a conditional expectation ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} such that for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}}, ρ​(X)=ρ​(ℰ​(X))𝜌𝑋𝜌ℰ𝑋\rho(X)=\rho({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X)) if and only if the orthogonal projection onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho is a conditional expectation.

This raises the question: For which faithful states ρ𝜌\rho is the orthogonal projection onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho is actually a conditional expectation?

4.1 Theorem.

Let ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} be a finite dimensional von Neumann algebra, and let 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} be a von Neumann subalgebra of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let ρ𝜌\rho be a faithful state on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, and let ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} be the modular operator on ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} defined by Δρ​(X)=ρ​X​ρ−1subscriptΔ𝜌𝑋𝜌𝑋superscript𝜌1\Delta_{\rho}(X)=\rho X\rho^{-1}. Let 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} be the orthogonal projection from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho. Then:

(1) 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real; i.e., it preserves self-adjointness, if and only if 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}.

(2) 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} if and only if for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}},

Δρ​(A)=Δρ𝒩​(A),subscriptΔ𝜌𝐴subscriptΔsubscript𝜌𝒩𝐴\Delta_{\rho}(A)=\Delta_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(A)\ , (4.1)

in which case Δρt​(A)=Δρ𝒩t​(A)subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑡𝜌𝐴subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝜌𝒩𝐴\Delta^{t}_{\rho}(A)=\Delta^{t}_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(A) for all t∈ℝ𝑡ℝt\in{\mathbb{R}}. Furthermore, (4.1) is valid for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}} if and only if 𝒜ρ​(A)=Asubscript𝒜𝜌𝐴𝐴{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(A)=A for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}.

4.2 Remark.

Part (2) of Theorem 4.1 is due to Accardi and Cecchini [2, Theorem 5.1]. In our finite dimensional context, we give a very simple proof; most of the proof below is devoted to (1).

Proof of Theorem 4.1.

Suppose that 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real. Then for all X∈Null​(𝒫ρ)𝑋Nullsubscript𝒫𝜌X\in{\rm Null}({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}), 0=(𝒫ρ​(X))∗=𝒫ρ​(X∗)0superscriptsubscript𝒫𝜌𝑋subscript𝒫𝜌superscript𝑋0=({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}(X))^{*}={\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}(X^{*}), so that Null​(𝒫ρ)Nullsubscript𝒫𝜌{\rm Null}({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}) is a self adjoint subspace of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}. Let m𝑚m denote the dimension of Null​(𝒫ρ)Nullsubscript𝒫𝜌{\rm Null}({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}). Then, applying the Gram-Schmidt Algorithm, one can produce an orthonormal basis {H1,…,Hm}subscript𝐻1…subscript𝐻𝑚\{H_{1},\dots,H_{m}\} of Null​(𝒫ρ)Nullsubscript𝒫𝜌{\rm Null}({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}) consisting of self-adjoint elements of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}.

The map X↦X​ρ1/2maps-to𝑋𝑋superscript𝜌12X\mapsto X\rho^{1/2} is unitary from (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩G​N​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{GNS,\rho}) to (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩H​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐻𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{HS,\rho}). Therefore for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}, and each j=1,…,m𝑗1…𝑚j=1,\dots,m, ⟨A​ρ1/2,Hj​ρ1/2⟩H​S=0subscript𝐴superscript𝜌12subscript𝐻𝑗superscript𝜌12𝐻𝑆0\langle A\rho^{1/2},H_{j}\rho^{1/2}\rangle_{HS}=0. Then since the map X↦X∗maps-to𝑋superscript𝑋X\mapsto X^{*} is an (antilinear) isometry on (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩H​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐻𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{HS,\rho}),

0=⟨(Hjρ1/2)∗,(Aρ1/2)∗,⟩H​S=Tr[HjρA∗]=Tr[HjΔρ(A∗)ρ]=⟨Hj,Δρ(A∗),⟩G​N​S,ρ.0=\langle(H_{j}\rho^{1/2})^{*},(A\rho^{1/2})^{*},\rangle_{HS}=\mathrm{Tr}[H_{j}\rho A^{*}]=\mathrm{Tr}[H_{j}\Delta_{\rho}(A^{*})\rho]=\langle H_{j},\Delta_{\rho}(A^{*}),\rangle_{GNS,\rho}\ .

Therefore, Δρ​(A∗)subscriptΔ𝜌superscript𝐴\Delta_{\rho}(A^{*}) is orthogonal to Null​(𝒫ρ)Nullsubscript𝒫𝜌{\rm Null}({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}) in (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩G​N​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{GNS,\rho}), and hence Δρ​(A∗)∈𝒩subscriptΔ𝜌superscript𝐴𝒩\Delta_{\rho}(A^{*})\in{\mathcal{N}}. Since A𝐴A is arbitrary in 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, it follows that 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}.

For the converse, suppose that 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}. Then 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρssuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌𝑠\Delta_{\rho}^{s} for all s∈ℝ𝑠ℝs\in{\mathbb{R}}, and in particular, 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under Δρ/12superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌absent12\Delta_{\rho}^{/12}. Then ρ1/2​𝒩=𝒩​ρ1/2superscript𝜌12𝒩𝒩superscript𝜌12\rho^{1/2}{\mathcal{N}}={\mathcal{N}}\rho^{1/2} as subspaces of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}; let 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}} denote this subspace of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, which is evidently self-adjoint. Let H=H∗∈ℳ𝐻superscript𝐻ℳH=H^{*}\in{\mathcal{M}}. Thus,

H​ρ1/2=(H​ρ1/2−A​ρ1/2)+A​ρ1/2andρ1/2​H=(ρ1/2​H−ρ1/2​B)+ρ1/2​Bformulae-sequence𝐻superscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12𝐴superscript𝜌12𝐴superscript𝜌12andsuperscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12𝐵superscript𝜌12𝐵H\rho^{1/2}=(H\rho^{1/2}-A\rho^{1/2})+A\rho^{1/2}\qquad{\rm and}\qquad\rho^{1/2}H=(\rho^{1/2}H-\rho^{1/2}B)+\rho^{1/2}B\

are the orthogonal decompositions of H​ρ1/2𝐻superscript𝜌12H\rho^{1/2} and ρ1/2​Hsuperscript𝜌12𝐻\rho^{1/2}H with respect to 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}}. Again since X↦X​ρ1/2maps-to𝑋𝑋superscript𝜌12X\mapsto X\rho^{1/2} is unitary from (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩G​N​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{GNS,\rho}) to (ℳ,⟨⋅,⋅⟩H​S,ρ)ℳsubscript⋅⋅𝐻𝑆𝜌({\mathcal{M}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{HS,\rho}), 𝒫ρ​(H)=Asubscript𝒫𝜌𝐻𝐴{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}(H)=A. Since X↦X∗maps-to𝑋superscript𝑋X\mapsto X^{*} is an isometry for the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product, and since 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}} is self adjoint,

ρ1/2​H=(ρ1/2​H−ρ1/2​A∗)+ρ1/2​A∗superscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12superscript𝐴superscript𝜌12superscript𝐴\rho^{1/2}H=(\rho^{1/2}H-\rho^{1/2}A^{*})+\rho^{1/2}A^{*}

is again an orthogonal decomposition of ρ1/2​Hsuperscript𝜌12𝐻\rho^{1/2}H with respect to 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}}, and by uniqueness, B=A∗𝐵superscript𝐴B=A^{*}. Thus,

ρ1/2​H=(ρ1/2​H−ρ1/2​A∗)+ρ1/2​A∗.superscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12superscript𝐴superscript𝜌12superscript𝐴\rho^{1/2}H=(\rho^{1/2}H-\rho^{1/2}A^{*})+\rho^{1/2}A^{*}\ .
