Hence it remains to show that H​ρ1/2−A∗​ρ1/2𝐻superscript𝜌12superscript𝐴superscript𝜌12H\rho^{1/2}-A^{*}\rho^{1/2} is orthogonal to 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}} in the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product. The general element of 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}} can be written as ρ1/2​Zsuperscript𝜌12𝑍\rho^{1/2}Z for Z​i​n​𝒩𝑍𝑖𝑛𝒩Z\ in{\mathcal{N}}. Then

⟨ρ1/2Z,Hρ1/2−A∗ρ1/2⟩H​S=Tr[Z∗(ρ1/2H−ρ1/2A∗)ρ1/2=⟨Zρ1/2,(ρ1/2H−ρ1/2A∗)⟩H​S.\langle\rho^{1/2}Z,H\rho^{1/2}-A^{*}\rho^{1/2}\rangle_{HS}=\mathrm{Tr}[Z^{*}(\rho^{1/2}H-\rho^{1/2}A^{*})\rho^{1/2}=\langle Z\rho^{1/2},(\rho^{1/2}H-\rho^{1/2}A^{*})\rangle_{HS}\ .

But we have seen above that ρ1/2​H−ρ1/2​A∗superscript𝜌12𝐻superscript𝜌12superscript𝐴\rho^{1/2}H-\rho^{1/2}A^{*} is orthogonal to 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}}, and Z​ρ1/2∈𝒦𝑍superscript𝜌12𝒦Z\rho^{1/2}\in{\mathcal{K}}. This proves (1).

To prove (2), note first of all that when (4.1)) is valid for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}, then ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} preserves 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} since the right side evidently belongs to 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}.

Now suppose the ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} preserves 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}. Let A,B∈𝒩𝐴𝐵𝒩A,B\in{\mathcal{N}}. Then A∗Δρ𝒩(δρ(B)))∈𝒩A^{*}\Delta_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(\delta_{\rho}(B)))\in{\mathcal{N}}, and then by the definition of ℰτsubscriptℰ𝜏{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} and cyclicity of the trace,

Tr​[ρ​(A∗​ρ𝒩​ρ−1​B​ρ​ρ𝒩−1)]=Tr​[A∗​ρ𝒩​ρ−1​B​ρ]=Tr​[ρ𝒩​(ρ−1​B​ρ​A∗)].Trdelimited-[]𝜌superscript𝐴subscript𝜌𝒩superscript𝜌1𝐵𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩1Trdelimited-[]superscript𝐴subscript𝜌𝒩superscript𝜌1𝐵𝜌Trdelimited-[]subscript𝜌𝒩superscript𝜌1𝐵𝜌superscript𝐴\mathrm{Tr}[\rho(A^{*}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}\rho^{-1}B\rho\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1})]=\mathrm{Tr}[A^{*}\rho_{\mathcal{N}}\rho^{-1}B\rho]=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(\rho^{-1}B\rho A^{*})]\ .

In the same way, using the fact that (ρ−1​B​ρ​A)∈𝒩superscript𝜌1𝐵𝜌𝐴𝒩(\rho^{-1}B\rho A)\in{\mathcal{N}} and cyclicity of the trace,

Tr​[ρ𝒩​(ρ−1​B​ρ​A∗)]=Tr​[B​ρ​A∗]=Tr​[ρ​A∗​B].Trdelimited-[]subscript𝜌𝒩superscript𝜌1𝐵𝜌superscript𝐴Trdelimited-[]𝐵𝜌superscript𝐴Trdelimited-[]𝜌superscript𝐴𝐵\mathrm{Tr}[\rho_{\mathcal{N}}(\rho^{-1}B\rho A^{*})]=\mathrm{Tr}[B\rho A^{*}]=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho A^{*}B]\ .

Altogether, ⟨A,ΔρN​(Δρ−1​(B))⟩G​N​S,ρ=⟨A,B⟩G​N​S,ρsubscript𝐴subscriptΔsubscript𝜌𝑁superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌1𝐵𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌subscript𝐴𝐵𝐺𝑁𝑆𝜌\langle A,\Delta_{\rho_{N}}(\Delta_{\rho}^{-1}(B))\rangle_{GNS,\rho}=\langle A,B\rangle_{GNS,\rho}. Since ΔρN​(Δρ−1​(B))∈𝒩subscriptΔsubscript𝜌𝑁superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌1𝐵𝒩\Delta_{\rho_{N}}(\Delta_{\rho}^{-1}(B))\in{\mathcal{N}}, and A𝐴A is arbitrary in 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, ΔρN​(Δρ−1​(B))=BsubscriptΔsubscript𝜌𝑁superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌1𝐵𝐵\Delta_{\rho_{N}}(\Delta_{\rho}^{-1}(B))=B, and hence Δρ−1​(B)=ΔρN−1​(B)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌1𝐵superscriptsubscriptΔsubscript𝜌𝑁1𝐵\Delta_{\rho}^{-1}(B)=\Delta_{\rho_{N}}^{-1}(B). Then Δρ−n​(B)=ΔρN−n​(B)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌𝑛𝐵superscriptsubscriptΔsubscript𝜌𝑁𝑛𝐵\Delta_{\rho}^{-n}(B)=\Delta_{\rho_{N}}^{-n}(B) for all n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in{\mathbb{N}}, and then it follows that Δρt​(B)=ΔρNt​(B)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜌𝑡𝐵superscriptsubscriptΔsubscript𝜌𝑁𝑡𝐵\Delta_{\rho}^{t}(B)=\Delta_{\rho_{N}}^{t}(B) for all t∈ℝ𝑡ℝt\in{\mathbb{R}}.

Finally, we show that (4.1) is valid for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}, then 𝒜ρ​(A)=Asubscript𝒜𝜌𝐴𝐴{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(A)=A for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}:

ℰτ​(ρ1/2​A​ρ1/2)=ℰτ​(Δρ1/2​(A)​ρ)=Δρ𝒩1/2​(A)​ℰτ​(ρ)=ρc​N​A1/2​A​ρ𝒩1/2.subscriptℰ𝜏superscript𝜌12𝐴superscript𝜌12subscriptℰ𝜏subscriptsuperscriptΔ12𝜌𝐴𝜌subscriptsuperscriptΔ12subscript𝜌𝒩𝐴subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌subscript𝜌𝑐𝑁superscript𝐴12𝐴superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho^{1/2}A\rho^{1/2})={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\Delta^{1/2}_{\rho}(A)\rho)=\Delta^{1/2}_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(A){\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho)=\rho_{cN}{A}^{1/2}A\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\ .

By (2) of Theorem 4.1, for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}, Δρ𝒩1/2​(A)=Δρ1/2​(A)subscriptsuperscriptΔ12subscript𝜌𝒩𝐴subscriptsuperscriptΔ12𝜌𝐴\Delta^{1/2}_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(A)=\Delta^{1/2}_{\rho}(A), and therefore

ℰτ,𝒩​(ρ1/2​A​ρ1/2)=ℰτ​(Δρ𝒩1/2​(A)​ρ)=Δρ1/2​(A)​ℰτ​(ρ)=ρ𝒩1/2​A​ρ𝒩1/2.subscriptℰ𝜏𝒩superscript𝜌12𝐴superscript𝜌12subscriptℰ𝜏subscriptsuperscriptΔ12subscript𝜌𝒩𝐴𝜌subscriptsuperscriptΔ12𝜌𝐴subscriptℰ𝜏𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12𝐴superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau,{\mathcal{N}}}(\rho^{1/2}A\rho^{1/2})={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\Delta^{1/2}_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(A)\rho)=\Delta^{1/2}_{\rho}(A){\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho)=\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}A\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}\ .

That is, A=ρ𝒩−1/2​ℰτ​(ρ1/2​A​ρ1/2)​ρ𝒩−1/2=𝒜ρ​(A)𝐴superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12subscriptℰ𝜏superscript𝜌12𝐴superscript𝜌12superscriptsubscript𝜌𝒩12subscript𝒜𝜌𝐴A=\rho_{{\mathcal{N}}}^{-1/2}{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho^{1/2}A\rho^{1/2})\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(A). On the other hand, when A=𝒜ρ​(A)𝐴subscript𝒜𝜌𝐴A={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(A) for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}, 𝒜ρsubscript𝒜𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} is a norm one projection onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}}, and by Tomiyama’s Theorem [37], it is a conditional expectation, and it satisfies ρ​(𝒜ρ​(X))​X𝜌subscript𝒜𝜌𝑋𝑋\rho({\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X))X for all X∈ℳ𝑋ℳX\in{\mathcal{M}}. Therefore, it must coincide with 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}, the orthogonal projection form ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho. Hence 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation. By what we proved earlier, this means that 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}, and then that (4.1) is valid for all A∈𝒩𝐴𝒩A\in{\mathcal{N}}. ∎

4.3 Theorem.

Let 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} denote the orthogonal projection of ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ρ𝜌\rho. Then

(1) 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation if and only if 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}.

(2) 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation if and only if 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real.

Proof.

Theorem 4.1 says that when ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} does not leave 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} invariant, 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is not even real, and hence is not a conditional expectation. On the other hand, when ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho} leaves 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} invariant, a theorem of Takesaki says that there exists a projection ℰℰ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} with unit norm from ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}} onto 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} that satisfies (1.15). By Tomiyama’s Theorem and remarks we have made in the introduction, this means that ℰ=𝒫ρℰsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}={\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}, and that 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation in the sense of Umegaki. This proves (1).

It is evident that if 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation, this 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real. On the other hand, if 𝒫ρsubscript𝒫𝜌{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real, then by Theorem 4.1, 𝒩𝒩{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under ΔρsubscriptΔ𝜌\Delta_{\rho}, and now (2) follows from (1). ∎

5 Strong Subadditivity

We recall the proof of equivalence of the strong-subadditivity relation and the monotonicity of relative entropy under partial traces, according to [18], in which it is shown that strong sub-additivity relation can be written in the following form: for ℋ=ℋ1⊗ℋ2⊗ℋ3ℋtensor-productsubscriptℋ1subscriptℋ2subscriptℋ3{\mathcal{H}}={\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{3} and ρ123∈ℬ​(ℋ)subscript𝜌123ℬℋ\rho_{123}\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}),

S(ρ12||ρ1⊗ρ2)≤S(ρ123||ρ1⊗ρ23),S(\rho_{12}||\rho_{1}\otimes\rho_{2})\leq S(\rho_{123}||\rho_{1}\otimes\rho_{23}), (5.1)

where ρ12=Trℋ3​ρ123subscript𝜌12subscriptTrsubscriptℋ3subscript𝜌123\rho_{12}=\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{3}}\rho_{123} etc. (See [18]). With 𝒩:=ℬ​(ℋ1⊗ℋ2)assign𝒩ℬtensor-productsubscriptℋ1subscriptℋ2{\mathcal{N}}:={\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2}),

S(ρ12||ρ1⊗ρ2)=S((ρ123)𝒩||(ρ1⊗ρ23)𝒩).S(\rho_{12}||\rho_{1}\otimes\rho_{2})=S((\rho_{123})_{\mathcal{N}}||(\rho_{1}\otimes\rho_{23})_{\mathcal{N}})\ .

The DPI inequality yields

S(ρ𝒩||σ𝒩)≤S(ρ||σ),S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\leq S(\rho||\sigma), (5.2)

for ρ,σ∈ℬ​(ℋ)𝜌𝜎ℬℋ\rho,\sigma\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}).

5.1 Lemma.

(Lieb, Ruskai [18]) Let ℋ=ℋ1⊗ℋ2⊗ℋ3ℋtensor-productsubscriptℋ1subscriptℋ2subscriptℋ3{\mathcal{H}}={\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{3}. The monotonicity of the relative entropy under partial traces holds for all states ρ,σ∈ℬ​(ℋ)𝜌𝜎ℬℋ\rho,\sigma\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}) if and only if the strong sub-additivity inequality

S​(ρ12)+S​(ρ23)−S​(ρ123)−S​(ρ2)≥0.𝑆subscript𝜌12𝑆subscript𝜌23𝑆subscript𝜌123𝑆subscript𝜌20S(\rho_{12})+S(\rho_{23})-S(\rho_{123})-S(\rho_{2})\geq 0. (5.3)

holds for all states ρ123∈ℋ1⊗ℋ2⊗ℋ3subscript𝜌123tensor-productsubscriptℋ1subscriptℋ2subscriptℋ3\rho_{123}\in{\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{3}.

Proof.

(MONO⇒⇒\Rightarrow SSA) From here it is clear that taking the CPTP to be a partial trace over the third space and ρ=ρ123𝜌subscript𝜌123\rho=\rho_{123}, σ=ρ1⊗ρ23𝜎tensor-productsubscript𝜌1subscript𝜌23\sigma=\rho_{1}\otimes\rho_{23} in (5.2) leads to (5.1).

(SSA⇒⇒\Rightarrow MONO) Let us take the space ℋ3subscriptℋ3{\mathcal{H}}_{3} to be 2-dimensional and the state ρ123subscript𝜌123\rho_{123} in the following form

ρ123=λ​ρ12′⊗E3+(1−λ)​ρ12′′⊗F3,subscript𝜌123tensor-product𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝜌′12subscript𝐸3tensor-product1𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝜌′′12subscript𝐹3\rho_{123}=\lambda\rho^{\prime}_{12}\otimes E_{3}+(1-\lambda)\rho^{\prime\prime}_{12}\otimes F_{3}, (5.4)

where E3subscript𝐸3E_{3} and F3subscript𝐹3F_{3} are orthogonal one-dimensional projections on ℋ3subscriptℋ3{\mathcal{H}}_{3} and λ∈[0,1]𝜆01\lambda\in[0,1]. Then the SSA relation (5.1) for this ρ123subscript𝜌123\rho_{123} is equivalent to the concavity property of the conditional entropy S​(ρ12∥ρ1)𝑆conditionalsubscript𝜌12subscript𝜌1S(\rho_{12}\|\rho_{1}), i.e. for any λ∈[0,1]𝜆01\lambda\in[0,1] and any ρ12′subscriptsuperscript𝜌′12\rho^{\prime}_{12} and ρ12′′subscriptsuperscript𝜌′′12\rho^{\prime\prime}_{12} above we have

λ​(S​(ρ12′)−S​(ρ2′))+(1−λ)​(S​(ρ12′′)−S​(ρ2′′))≤S​(ρ12)−S​(ρ2).𝜆𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝜌′12𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝜌′21𝜆𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝜌′′12𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝜌′′2𝑆subscript𝜌12𝑆subscript𝜌2\lambda(S(\rho^{\prime}_{12})-S(\rho^{\prime}_{2}))+(1-\lambda)(S(\rho^{\prime\prime}_{12})-S(\rho^{\prime\prime}_{2}))\leq S(\rho_{12})-S(\rho_{2}). (5.5)

Recall that a function f:[0,1]→ℝ:𝑓→01ℝf:[0,1]\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is called operator convex if for all matrices A,B𝐴𝐵A,B with eigenvalues in [0,1]01[0,1] and 0<λ<10𝜆10<\lambda<1 the following holds

f​(λ​A+(1−λ)​B)≤λ​f​(A)+(1−λ)​f​(B).𝑓𝜆𝐴1𝜆𝐵𝜆𝑓𝐴1𝜆𝑓𝐵f(\lambda A+(1-\lambda)B)\leq\lambda f(A)+(1-\lambda)f(B). (5.6)

Note that if an operator concave function f𝑓f is homogeneous (i.e. f​(t​A)=t​f​(A)𝑓𝑡𝐴𝑡𝑓𝐴f(tA)=tf(A) for all t>0𝑡0t>0), then for positive matrices A𝐴A and B𝐵B

dd​t|t=0​f​(A+t​B):=limt→01t​{f​(A+t​B)−f​(A)}≥f​(B)assignevaluated-at𝑑𝑑𝑡𝑡0𝑓𝐴𝑡𝐵subscript→𝑡01𝑡𝑓𝐴𝑡𝐵𝑓𝐴𝑓𝐵\frac{d}{dt}\bigg{|}_{t=0}f(A+tB):=\lim_{t\rightarrow 0}\frac{1}{t}\{f(A+tB)-f(A)\}\geq f(B) (5.7)

the above limit exits. To see this, use the homogeneity first, and then the concavity of f𝑓f in the following way

f​(A+t​B)𝑓𝐴𝑡𝐵\displaystyle f(A+tB) =(1+t)​f​(11+t​A+t1+t​B)absent1𝑡𝑓11𝑡𝐴𝑡1𝑡𝐵\displaystyle=(1+t)f\left(\frac{1}{1+t}A+\frac{t}{1+t}B\right) (5.8)
≥(1+t)​(11+t​f​(A)+t1+t​f​(B))absent1𝑡11𝑡𝑓𝐴𝑡1𝑡𝑓𝐵\displaystyle\geq(1+t)\left(\frac{1}{1+t}f(A)+\frac{t}{1+t}f(B)\right) (5.9)
=f​(A)+t​f​(B).absent𝑓𝐴𝑡𝑓𝐵\displaystyle=f(A)+tf(B). (5.10)

Take a conditional entropy as this function f𝑓f:

f​(γ12):=S​(γ12)−S​(γ2).assign𝑓subscript𝛾12𝑆subscript𝛾12𝑆subscript𝛾2f(\gamma_{12}):=S(\gamma_{12})-S(\gamma_{2}).

Then the derivative is

dd​t​f​(γ12+t​ω12)=−Tr​ω12​ln⁡(γ12+t​ω12)+Tr​ω2​ln⁡(γ2+t​ω2).𝑑𝑑𝑡𝑓subscript𝛾12𝑡subscript𝜔12Trsubscript𝜔12subscript𝛾12𝑡subscript𝜔12Trsubscript𝜔2subscript𝛾2𝑡subscript𝜔2\frac{d}{dt}f(\gamma_{12}+t\omega_{12})=-\mathrm{Tr}\omega_{12}\ln(\gamma_{12}+t\omega_{12})+\mathrm{Tr}\omega_{2}\ln(\gamma_{2}+t\omega_{2}).

Since the conditional entropy is concave and homogeneous, applying inequality (5.7) leads to the monotonicity of the relative entropy under partial traces (5.2). ∎

The stability bound proved here has obvious consequences for the SSA inequality, and can be used to give a quantitative version of the result [14] of Hayden, Josza, Petz and Winter. For another improvement to the SSA inequality, namely

S​(ρ12)+S​(ρ23)−S​(ρ123)−S​(ρ2)≥2​max⁡{S​(ρ1)−S​(ρ13),S​(ρ3)−S​(ρ13)},𝑆subscript𝜌12𝑆subscript𝜌23𝑆subscript𝜌123𝑆subscript𝜌22𝑆subscript𝜌1𝑆subscript𝜌13𝑆subscript𝜌3𝑆subscript𝜌13S(\rho_{12})+S(\rho_{23})-S(\rho_{123})-S(\rho_{2})\geq 2\max\{S(\rho_{1})-S(\rho_{13}),S(\rho_{3})-S(\rho_{13})\}\ , (5.11)

see [7].
